title: M4 Hinged Extruder, Reinforced Guidler
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Hinged Wade-Extruder block for M4 idler bolts, with a handle on the idler and a few fixes. Now updated, see below :)
When I first printed Greg's Hinged Accessible extruder, I had to hack out the top captive nut holes that idler bolts went through since they were under-sized in one direction, then ended up accidentally over-sizing the holes with my multitool's chisel, so I used M4 nuts and bolts instead. (I wasn't even sure at the time if it was meant to be M3 or M4 fitting since the bolt holes were loose)
I since realised that it's much easier to get enough idler pressure on the filament while using the same stiff springs that support my printbed, which barely fit in the area of a form-A M4 washer, while suggested pen springs on M3 bolts are nearly impossible to tighten enough and it's hard to find M3 bolts long enough in the first place.
So, I've re-designed both the extruder and idler with holes that should be large enough to not need reaming for M4 fittings, while keeping over my double-option hot-end mounting slots from a design that I produced before finding the default STL-import options in SolidWorks that had prevented me editing things from STL before. Things fixed:
  • Motor mounting bolt-holes have 2mm added depth, because I've always found it extremely difficult to fit a motor to this bracket using M3x10mm bolts and single washers after removing the support material, since they barely reach the other side; the M3x20's that I have are too long, and who the hell gets 15mm bolts?
  • A slot has been cut out of the bottom at the motor-bracket end of the extruder body, which I have had to do with a pen-knife before since otherwise it wouldn't fit on a Mendel x-carriage due to collision with a bolt head.
  • I reinforced a stress-concentrating corner just above the hinge point on the idler part, since I've had a couple of those break on me there. I also added a small thumb-handle to the idler, as I've seen a larger one elsewhere.
    • The J-Head mounting body is based upon direct measurements of a Mk.IV hot-end using calipers. It fits better than any I've found yet. Update 1.1:
  • Enlarged the guidler hinge captive nut hole, it is actually usable now without instantly breaking the hinge, yay!
  • Reinforced one side of the guidler's filament guide, which previously broke on me and caused a print to fail.
  • Also added M3 versions.
Why does this idler handle have a hole in it? You tell me. Maybe you can loop a string through it for easier grabbing or attach something to it, I dunno.

comments.text: I like your changes, especially the thicker motor bracket, and the j-head bolt holes.
comments.author: NumberSix

comments.text: I first saw a notch added behind the filament path in http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:16928 , and since then GregFrost has made a similar alteration in his latest extruder model. Its purpose is to allow you to clean out individual teeth on a hobbed bolt without removing it from the extruder.

title: Tronxy x3a Adjustable Autolevel Sensor Mount

description.text:
This is a simple Adjustable autolevel sensor mount for the Tronxy x3a.

We all know well enough that adjusting the stock autolevel sensor to the right height is a pain in the butt. There was no way to reliably set the height of the sensor. This has caused me numerous amounts of grief as the print head starts to smash itself into the print bed the moment a print is started. Hence this part to alleviate that pain.

Additional Parts (you should have some extra from your assembly of the printer):
2 x 8mm M3
1 x 25mm M3
2 x 25mm or greater M3
2 x springs (obtainable from your average ball point pen)
2 x M3 screws that came with your Tronxy xy-08n autolevel sensor.
1 x Tronxy xy-08n sensor

Printer:

Tronxy x3a

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

30%

Notes:

I used repetierHost that came with the printer, as well as the bundled cura engine slicer to slice the part. I added a brim to ensure that the print head is extruding proper before it reaches the main part.

Assembly
  1. Mount the base part (prt0002.stl) to where the autolevel sensor used to sit with the two 8mm M3 machine screws.
  2. Mount the autolevel sensor to the sliding mount (prt0003.stl), ensuring that the screws do not extend past the back of the sliding mount.
  3. Slide the sliding mount into the base part.
  4. Thread the two 25mm or greater machine screws into the two compression springs.
  5. Affix the screw + spring assembly to the two holes at the top of the base part.
  6. Ensure that the sliding mount can be push downwards but still be able to return to the top via the springs' tension.
  7. Screw in the final 25mm M3 screw into the hole in the middle at the top of the base part. (This is your adjustment screw)
  8. Finally, you can adjust the height of your autolevel sensor by turning the adjustment screw.

Recommendations to adjusting the autolevel sensor height

You'd want to first have the sensor at the lowest position allowed by the springs and screws.
Run the auto level command on the printer then check the height again by printing a test piece (a small one will do). Printing of a test piece will take into account your z-offset settings on the x3a.

Do this several times until you have the perfect height for your sensor. Ideally your first layer of prints should be slightly squashed and there should not be any gaps between the lines of the brim.

Notes:

Support for the hook needed

Hair dryer holder with the nozzle pointing away from the wall.
This has the advantage that:
a) you can turn the dryer on as soon as you grab it off of the holder since the thumb is in the correct position. Saves you about .5 sec every time you use your hair dryer :-)
b) it fits in very small niches for example between the medicine cabinet and the wall (as it is in my bathroom)
c) it results in a very simple design that is sturdy, quick to print, and easy to install (two screws).

I made this since I didn't like all the available holders that were already available on thingiverse.
The simple designs all made the hair dryer hang sideways taking a lot of space on the wall that I didn't have available.

I hope this will be useful for other people.

Nothing really needed after print.
PLA can be annealed after print to increase strength. not really needed.

The screw holes are designed and countersunk for #6 wood screws. Best to use rust proof screws so the screw heads don't corrode in the humid environment of a bathroom.

remixed_from.author: Jabird73
remixed_from.title: 1"  Ring Mount MIL-STD 1913 with Weaver Mount

description.text:
Buying scope rings that are the right height for you and your particular rifle can be a little difficult. There is a lot of guesswork involved if you're not very experienced. Many manufacturers will not let you return rings that have been mounted, so you essentially have to pay a ton of money to test things out and even then you may settle for something that's close enough but not perfect.

I bought myself a new 34mm scope for Christmas and didn't want to go through that again (especially since the rings I want are over $200 for a pair) so I made these. They vary in height from 1" to 1.5"* by .125". Height is measured from the top of the rail to the center of the scope tube.

Slide the rings on to the rail, then pop the scope in the rings.

I shouldn't have to say this, but USE FOR TESTING ONLY. DO NOT ATTEMPT TO LIVE FIRE YOUR RIFLE USING THESE.

Heavily remixed from https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1685787

*Note that Nightforce does not make 1.25" height rings

remixed_from.author: blomker
remixed_from.title: Kossel Mini NEMA17 Extruder for 1.75mm Filament

description.text:
A compact direct drive bowden extruder for 1.75mm and a MK8 style hobbed pulley. The OpenScad is almost completely parametrizable, so it can be adjusted to fit other hobbed pulleys as well. The mounting plate can be removed from OpenScad easily. I have used a 13x8mm, 5mm bore brass hobbed pulley, because it was easy to acquire here in Germany. The used MK8 style hobbed pulley can be ordered at the following websites:
  • https://www.reprapsource.com/en/show/6889
  • http://reprapteile.de/mechanisch/direct-drive-geraendelter-pulley-drive-gear.html
    • Note: I ordered a suitable compression spring later, so it's not visible on all of the images. UPDATE 2015-10-13: Designed alternative idler to solve breaking of bearing support
    UPDATE 2015-03-17: Updated idler for better MK7 drive gear support
    UPDATE 2014-11-13: Added push-fit bowden inlet option
    UPDATE 2014-09-22: Fixed OpenScad file due to non-manifold vertexes between base and filament tunnel after inspection with MeshLab, exported STL
    UPDATE 2014-06-01: Removed the work-in-progress flag after extensive testing and positive feedback from the community.
    UPDATE 2014-04-27: Placed base and idler "printer ready" beneath each other, added compact_direct_drive_extruder.stl with base and idler combined
    UPDATE 2014-04-07: Replaced tensioner hole with slot on idler, added funnel on bowden side of base for easier filament insertion

• Important: If you're not using the same 13x8mm drive gear as I do, adjust the drive gear dimensions in the OpenSCAD file and export idler and base as separate STL files.
  • Choose suitable version: normal inlet or push-fit bowden inlet
  • Slice model and print base plate and idler separately. I used Slic3r with 0.2mm layer thickness and a 0.5mm J-Head nozzle.
  • Use 2mm drill to clean filament path on base plate.
  • Use M5 screw tap to cut thread for push-fit bowden connector on base plate and bearing holder on idler.
  • Attach push-fit bowden connector(s) on base plate.
  • Attach 608zz bearing to idler and secure it with a M5 washer and a M5x10mm allen head screw. If you are using the alternative idler insert the 608 bearing between idler parts and secure it with a M5x14mm allen head screw.
  • Attach NEMA17-Motor with three M3x8mm allen head screws (use countersunk holes).
  • Attach idler to base plate with a M3x16mm allen head screw. Avoid to much tension to allow idler moving freely.
  • Fasten hobbed pulley on NEMA17 stepper motor shaft. Adjust its height accordingly.
  • Insert Filament into extruder.
  • Insert M3 nut into base plate slot.
  • Use M3 allen head screw of suitable length with washers and a spring to apply pressure on filament.
  • Happy extruding ;-)

Parts used (BOM):
  • 1x base plate (printed)
  • 1x idler (printed)
  • 1x hobbed pulley 13x8mm, 5mm bore or similar
  • 1x M5 push-fit bowden connector (5mm thread) for 4mm OD bowden tubes (add another one for bowden inlet version)
  • 1x 608zz bearing
  • 1x M5 washer
  • 1x M5x10mm allen head screw (M5x14mm for altenative idler)
  • 3x M3x8mm allen head screws
  • 1x M3x16mm allen head screw (M3x20mm for alternative idler)
  • 1x M3 nut
  • 2x M3 washers
  • 1x compression spring 3mm ID
  • 1x M3 allen head screw with suitable length for the selected spring
    • Tools used:
  • M5 manual screw tap
  • 2mm drill

comments.text: Hi,
comments.author: asking

comments.text:
Hi asking. Thanks for your comment.
Doing a pre-extruder setup seems to be a fiddly task. Both stepper motors will run the same rotational speed if connected in parallel, but I wonder if the drive gears effective diameter will always be equal on both extruders. Minor differences in the filament diameter or idler pressure could change the effective diameter on the drive gear and therefore the extruding speed. Under some circumstances this could lead to a "breaking" pre-extruder, putting a bigger load on the regular extruder than without. But I'm interested in your results. Did it work as expected?
Regards,
schlotzz

comments.text: Can anyone help me with open scad? I need to increase the frame plate holes up to 8mm with a 13mm head hex screw and 8mm of depth.
comments.author: BerniApple

comments.text:
Hi BerniApple. I'll try to help you with customizing the OpenScad file to your needs.
At first, the mounting plate should be wider and longer to give you enough room for 13mm screw heads (see line 44/45, base_width/base_length). I set it to base_width = 20 and base_length = 80. At second, the position of the holes must be adjusted to shift a little inwards. Have a look at lines 132/133 and change -6 / +6 to -10 / +10. At last adjust the size of holes itsself. In lines 164/165 change the radius from m3_wide_radius / m3_head_radius to the radi of you screw / screw head with a little extra margin. For example a M8 screw with a 13mm head should go with "8/2 + 0.3" instead of m3_wide_radius and "13/2 + 0.3" instead of m3_head_radius.
Hopefully you get along with this short guide. Please feel free to adjust the parameters to your needs and get back to me whenever there are any further questions according OpenScad.
Regards,
schlotzz

comments.text: I really like this design, but I'm having an issue with it. It extrudes plastic perfectly until the plastic reaches the nozzle of the hot end. At this point, the extruder will just begin to grind at the filament. Sometimes I can push on the idler more and it moves about an inch, but then it refuses to go any further. Do you have any suggestions to fix this?
comments.author: molmsted98

comments.text:
Hi molmsted98. Thanks for your feedback about my extruder design. If your filament gets stuck, even if you're pushing by hand, something else might be an issue.
Is this the first extruder in this setup. If not, did you experience any problems with other extruders? Which material and hotend do you have? Sometimes PLA gets stuck if the hotend is not cooled properly. Did you check the hotend temperature? Maybe it's too low due to a misconfigured firmware or faulty thermistor. Or maybe your hotend nozzle is clogged. Did any material exit the nozzle? If not, maybe your hotend is not assembled properly and the filament path is blocked by a misalignment.
Please feel free to get back to me for further consultation. Hopefully the problem can be solved.
comments.author: molmsted98

comments.text: I previously used a different extruder, which caused no issues. I tried pushing the filament through the hot end by hand, and it went through with no problems. Is it possible that my extruder motor doesn't have enough torque to overcome going through the hot end?
comments.author: schlotzz

comments.text:
Hm... If the drive gear grinds at the filament, the motor seems to have enough torque. Otherwise the stepper would stall and loose steps. Did your last extruder have a MK8 drive gear, too? If you push on the idler, it moves some more and then stops. Does the motor stall in this case?
Could you post a picture or two of your extruder loaded with filament (e.g. as a make) for further inspection?
comments.author: molmsted98

comments.text: My previous extruder was a Greg's, so direct drive is all new to me. I think the motor stalls, if by that you mean begins to make a different sound. Here it is loaded with filament. https://imgur.com/a/no2az
comments.author: schlotzz

comments.text: The filament does not get bend. That's good. If the motor stops, makes louder humming noises or makes kind of click noises while the drive gear turns for some degrees backwards out of nothing: that's stalling. Maybe it does help to increase the idler pressure and the power of your stepper driver.
comments.author: molmsted98

comments.text: It stalls very infrequently. It's now even having a hard time retracting. I adjusted the idler to various pressures with no increase in performance. I also raised the voltage of the stepper, and that did not help either.
comments.author: schlotzz

comments.text: How much torque (Ncm) does your stepper motor have? Maybe its to weak?
comments.author: molmsted98

comments.text: The motor has a torque of 47 N/cm. Does adjusting the voltage do anything to the torque?
comments.author: schlotzz

comments.text: Yes, indeed. The higher the current, the more power will be transfered to the stepper motor, which will result in higher torque and more heat. So basically it's a trade off situation... Just have a look at these sites: http://reprap.org/wiki/StepperMotor#Purchasing_a_motor and http://reprap.org/wiki/Stepper_torque
comments.author: molmsted98

comments.text: Hello. I've been printing for a bit now using your simple design. However I cannot print above 40mm/s without skipping steps. Can you let me know what current (vref) and micro step you run. Also do you have a "high torque" stepper? Thank you.

comments.text: Is there a version of this that lets you easily switch filament? There is this design http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:287287 which is actually made for QU-BD but I like the design of the idler.
comments.author: bilalasd

comments.text:
Hi bilalasd. I'm not quite sure what you mean with "easily switch filament". For switching filament there exist two methods.
I usually let the extruder run backwards by the length of the bowden tube, enter the new filament and extrude by the length of the tube. All work is done by the stepper, you don't even need to release the idler screw. Easy as pie.
If you like to change the filament by hand, all you need to do is releasing the idler screw. The filament can be removed by pulling it out. Due to the funnel like design the new filament enters the bowden tube by itself. Just slide it in and tighten the idler screw afterwards.
comments.author: bilalasd

comments.text: Hi sobo84. There are two different versions of the extruder body. One is used for a push fit connector on the outlet side (towards the hot end), the other one is used for push fit connectors on both sides. The inlet side means the side the filament is fed into (towards the spool). Some people use bowden tubes on both sides...

comments.author: osgibson

comments.text: That fixed it for me, thank you so much.
comments.author: schlotzz

comments.text: This may be a silly question (newb here) but with Bowden extruders is there any preference between mounting  it to the side of the printer or overhead feeding down? Seems like the required bend in the filament/tubing would be minimized by mounting overhead in the center?
comments.author: John10

comments.text: Hi John10. I mounted my extruder on the side of my kossel mini, the outlet facing upwards, so that the bowden tube has only one wide loop (180° turn) without getting a sharp kink. Mounting it on the top, the outlet facing sidewards, should be an option, too, but I haven't tested it by myself, yet.
comments.author: John10

comments.text: Thank you for your reply schlotzz. I don't know why but I had been thinking of either mounting on the side directed at the hot end or on the top pointed straight down - it never occurred to me to put it at right angles so you may have saved me a lot of grief - thanks again!
comments.author: schlotzz

comments.author: Makarov_sl

comments.text:
Hi Makarov_sl. Thanks a lot for your feedback.
Due to not owning an E3D-hotend I'm not 100% sure about what you mean with "bigger inlet". I assume you're talking about the push-fit bowden connector. The connectors used in my design have an outer diameter of 5mm. You mentioned your connector has OD 1/8" (3.175mm) and therefore is smaller. Are you sure about the size of your connector?
comments.author: Makarov_sl

comments.text:
I am in the same business, that is creating an extruder for my E3D v6, and I guess he means this coupling:
http://e3d-online.com/Mechanical/Bowden/Threaded-Bowden-Coupling-1.75mm-Filament
The dimensions got me a bit confused at first as well, but it does say thread size 1/8" BSPT (British Standard Pipe Thread), not plain 1/8" measurement. According to http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/British_Standard_Pipe 1/8" BSPT means a thread major diameter of 9.728 mm, and a minor ditto of 8.565 mm. Mystery solved.
comments.author: schlotzz

comments.text: Thanks for this useful hint. I haven't thought of BSPT... :)
comments.author: magu

comments.text: Those darn confusing Brits! (... says the weird and crazy Swede)

comments.text: The BNC3D Sigma machines use 3mm filament, with a bowden tube and direct drive! Richrap has a few reviews of the machine. comments.text: Can the filament outlet area be made closer to the drive gear so soft/flexible filament does not pop out of the side. Using some of the softer ABS it has bunched up and popped out many times from the side.
comments.author: crunchtime2k

comments.text: Hi crunchtime2k. Thanks for your feedback according my extruder design. The inlet/outlet areas can be made closer easily by changing only one value in the OpenSCAD file. Please open the file and look for the comment line "// middle cutout for drive gear". Continue two lines after this comment and adjust "cylinder(r = 11.25 + extra_radius..." to "cylinder(r = 6 + extra_radius...". Change the radius according to your needs. Please note, that you have to add proper support via your slicer software.

comments.text:
Better still, get a pass through bowden connector, increase (or drill out) filament path to 4 mm, and let the PTFE-tubing go all the way to the gears. comments.text: I haven't tried a MK8 pulley yet. I set my stepper motor to half steps which gives me 90% of original holding torque. I was pushing it with 4.95kg/cm. I sure a planetary gear stepper would work or a beefy NEMA 17 from Anaheim Automation would be able to push the 3mm.

Hi ipblythe. The OpenScad file is almost completely parametrizable. You just may change the parameter "filament_diameter" to 3 instead of 1.75, although I'm not sure if a 3mm filament will work with a M5 bowden push-fit connector. I once tried drilling one up to 3.2mm ID, so that a 3mm will fit through, but I had to be carefull no to damage the M5 thread.
Please give it a try! I'm looking forward hearing if it'll work or not.

title: Bed leveling bolt and knob for aluminum extrusions of Anycubic Kossel

description.text:
This thing supposed to replace Anycubic bed mounts with no need for any metal parts but bolt and nut already used in old mounts.

Sources is there:
https://cad.onshape.com/documents/00754f31c201007badc391f4/w/6c9d9fca393489e56ca8e34e/e/67f31d5c629758d1cc4a894e
(some times onshape won't let you to download the cad files, just ask here in comments if this happens, I will upload snapshots of these files here for you)

I started by cutting a bit of plastic from electronhackses design but realized that it will not fit my needs well, so I made these from scratch.

To ease the confusion, this is the differences:
Nut +1 thread is 1mm wider. Because some printers is not so accurate.
Bolt +1 hole is 1mm deeper. Because some people supplied with shorter bolts.
+1 and non +1 parts are compatible, there is no other differences.
+1 mm for thread will only add ~0.3 mm of tolerance because thread surface is 60°.

There is 90% chance you will need both +1 parts.

Kossel don't really need those to level the bed as you can just adjust limit switches, but hey, I just want to have it.

Feel free to use this on terms of CC-BY-SA or GNU LGPL v3 license.
2 slowpokes: feel free to sell either files or prints or just earn money from ads on yourtube.
Just don't forget to mention my authorship and let your client (or viewer) have the same rights I grant you over this thing.

UPD: added +2 versions. These are just smaller +1s. In case you want something slim.
Should be intercompatible with every other version.

title: Jobs Peak Nevada
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is a small slice of the Carson Range / eastern Sierra Nevada mountains. Jobs Peak is a prominent mountain when viewed from Carson Valley.

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Creator Pro

Infill:

15

Notes:

I found printing a raft helps keep the outer edges from curling.

Used the 30m GeoTiff from USGS (https://nationalmap.gov/elevation.html).
Used QGIS to work with the raster data, location, etc.
Used 3DEM to convert to DEM
Used AccuTrans 3D to convert DEM to STL
Used Microsoft 3D Paint to emboss the title
Used Flashprint to slice.

Definitely need a smoother workflow, but I was eager to just get results so used what I could find quickly. The valley portion of the print needs some refinement.

print_settings.Notes:: Once printing on the side, have your slicer program use a raft or a brim once these will have a small footprint on the printer bed.

description.text: Made these for a softer landing option for the Peon230 although they would probably work for similar sized drones. They are very springy and absorb impacts well, for these to work effectively the open end must be facing outward from the drone. This way if you come down at a angle it will allow them to flex the most. Having them face outward also allows them to absorb vibrations & impacts well if the drone is moving forward or backwards for a slide landing. Will work with the 3mm bolt hole that the legs already have a spot for. Print them on their side so there will be no need for any support also you may want to use rafts as they will have a very small footprint on the print bed. I have had very good results with PLA @ 100% infill. Ver 2 - Edges are now flat to allow better print bed adhesion (so thin already this wasn't really needed in the first place) and removed the hex nut opening on the inside to maintain mount thickness.

title: Anet A6 Y Axis Belt Tensioner

description.text:
I was using https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1959208 until the frames broke - the use of a nut makes them too weak to actually last any length of time

Taking lessons learned from the failures of the one above, I designed my own with the following improvements:

  • The area where the bearings mount have a standoff so that the bearings can rotate freely
  • The frames have a nut trap on one frame and a counterbore on the other so an M3 cap head screw can be used to mount the bearings
  • The frame arms are now correctly spaced and sized. I found that the originals didn't fit as their spacing was out, a fair bit of filing was required
  • I've done away with the requirement to use nuts to mount the frames to the front plate. The cutouts required for nuts severely weakened the frames. The holes are 25mm deep, and should be tapped with an M3 tap
  • The front plate has been reduced in size and has counterbores so that cap head screws can be used to fasten the frames

title: 3D Scanner - Low Budget Photogrammetry Setup
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
UPDATE: There is a video of the full workflow and the parts and freeware used on youtube: https://youtu.be/NzJlzrXzJ7k

You can see some of my scans here: https://www.thingiverse.com/3dTM/collections/3d-scans

I have been fascinated with 3D printing for some years. Even though the number of free models and good modeling software is steadily increasing, I needed a high-quality 3D scanner, that allows me to create my own models based on real things for 3D printing. Current scanning devices are either inaccurate or still quite expensive. Good "consumer" devices start at ca. 2000€.

Using the technique photogrammetry (also called: structure from motion, short: sfm), led me to some amazing 3D Scans. For instance: coins, small figurines, jewelry and even working security keys, ...

The only thing needed is a decent camera and some software. Basically you take pictures of an object from as many different angles as possible. Next a software has to analyze those pictures and identify common features, that are visible from different angles. With those features, the camera positions can be calculated and a dense point cloud of the model can be formed. Depending on the software, this process can take up to several hours (or even days) of computing time.
As the quality of the 3D model highly depends on the number and quality of the photos, I decided to build the following 3D scanning device, which automates taking photos.
Basically it is a modified turntable, that has a second rotational degree of freedom. Instead of moving the camera around the object, it is fixed in position and the object can be turned horizontally and vertically. In principle, the pictures could be taken manually with a mobile phone's camera. But I highly recommend using a photographic camera, which allows manual settings for shutter and exposure time, as these (and other) settings have to be controllable. Furthermore, the use of a remote shutter-release allows the process to be fully automated, which is really helpful, when you need to take 200+ photos of one object. All the 3D models presented here have been created using a 10 year old Fujifilm S100FS (which now costs less than 100€) and a refined RR-80 remote shutter-release, that works with many other camera-models as well. The photos have been processed with Agisoft Photoscan Standard (179$), but there are freeware solutions available, that do a similar job.

This device can be used for models of up to 15cm in all directions, but the principle can easily be aplied to larger models.

I will update this model and details on the electronics and workflow soon.

The Model is optimized for two Stepper motor 28BYJ-48 with Stepper motor driver ULN2003.

See the scan process:
https://youtu.be/-G-nuKzgAQc

And a closeup:
https://youtu.be/Iey_DxJn7Eo

comments.author: sergroza

comments.text: I'm a bit surprised, as I always thought that for photogrammetry to work, you'd need a changing background (like you get when moving the camera around an object) for the software to work properly. This project has a static background, and still gives excellent results, so my initial belief is clearly just not true.
comments.author: mroek

comments.text: Concerning the moving background you were  completely right, BUT there are several ways to handle static background. First, on the software side, it is possible to mask unwanted areas (background or reflections). And second, you could create a featureless background (e.g. black) so the software will "ignore" these areas. Different programs have different abilities in handling static background, sometimes masking is absolutely necessary, sometimes it is not needed at all. I am still trying to figure out, how to handle this. And keep in mind, that a black background is not fully black as there will always be some fluctuations on the foto. But there are ways, to replace for instance all near-black pixels with one color, which helps a lot. See the attached picture of a 50ct coin, which is covert in chalk powder to reduce reflection and add features to the surface.

author: tristomietitoredeituit

description.text:
Blinders

I wanted to try making some blinders to attach to my glasses. I have a bright window to my side when I'm working. It's great to have the light, but I find it easier to focus on my monitor if I block the light coming into my peripheral vision.

Getting the size of the clip correct was tricky, so I put in an option to print only that section of the blinder. This way you're able to quickly print a couple sizes to find the right fit.

Printing

I found that printing them standing up worked well. My printer doesn't print well without a base, so this way I was able to have a small base. Also it's easier to remove supports that are between the clip and the base than between the clip and the shield.

Customisation

I made most of the measurements, including the side of the shield and dimensions for the clip parameters. This should make it easier to fit them to your glasses. I designed the blinders in OpenSCAD and the SCAD file is available here as well as in GitHub.

Using the Customizer on Thingiverse will allow you to change all of the variables except the shield dimensions. You can do that by downloading and editing the SCAD file.

Repo

https://github.com/jeffhiltz/blinders

author: thunder_88

print_settings.Notes:: This is a complex build, many parts, each with different printing requirements. It was all printed within a 20cm x 20cm x 18cm build space with a 0.4mm nozzle. 3 perimeters for the hull makes it a little heavy, I recommend trying a test print of 1 perimeter just to see how light you can make it on your printer without producing holes. It is easier to add ballast than to take it away. I'd like to find a technique that allows 2 perimeters on the outside of the hull and 1 perimeter on the inside. You need to start by considering the size of the parts you can't change - the motor and prop shaft.

description.text:
Radio controlled motor launch, based on plans of a 1926 motor launch by John Hacker. A 25 feet motor boat originally with a 150 HP engine, scaled to 723 mm long for printing in six sections. Requires 140W motor (2830 750Kv brushless), 1.8Ah 3S battery and low profile servo for the rudder. With this power it manages to plane at what looks like scale speed. On the water: https://vimeo.com/251072600

It would be possible but tricky to re-scale, many Openscad scripts ended up being hard-coded to the scaled size. Important variables are at the top of scripts but precedence isn't necessarily sensible.

Thingiverse doesn't allow upload of all the file types. The ribs/stations and keel line were traced using minimal free plans available. X-splines (taken from a mathematical manuscript) were then used to make them continuous. They were then converted into a solid 3D object using a custom written gawk script. The continuous rib+keel points were used to make more continuous curves from bow to stern. These were then stitched together to make an initial solid hull shape that had many more polygons than necessary but faithfully reproduced the hull shape. The full build description and all the original scripts and sources are at http://abatis.org.uk/boatpage/ (my project page).

So far it has been out on the water on four days, various rudder sizes and propeller sizes have been tested. With this power combiniation it is about as fast as it can be. I can also conclude it contains no major design flaws, the only recommendation is to print it lighter than 3 perimeters.

description.text: I used the stand I'm remixing for a while until the cable went dead. Upon inspection it turned out the screw used to fix it has damaged it over time, so I designed very similar stand for an arbitrary lightning cable. It prevents screw from damaging the connector (to some certain extent) by having a thin plastic layer in between. Which should break away from the main body once you tighten the screw.

A quadrisection of a sphere into four identical parts with some novel attributes:
  • The parts have no overhangs.
  • The flat \'bottom\' is completely concealed after assembly; there are no flat spots on the exterior of the sphere.
  • Exterior is made entirely of \'sidewalls\' where the resolution of FDM really shines.
    • My test samples were built in transparent PVC on a Solido SD300 Pro, but my goal was to design a Makerbot-friendly shape. Based on feedback from friends, I\'ve adjusted the contours so the pieces \'grab\' onto each other after assembly. More pictures and discussion at my SD300 blog entry at http://mysd300.blogspot.com/2010/05/novel-decompositions-of-sphere.html

After you build four of these they should fit together to form a ball.
Note: the parts fit together with their build planes at right angles, so it\'ll doubtless be affected by any geometric distortions.

comments.text: Printing this on the MakerBot with a raft results in each piece being one layer thicker than desired.  The linear stripes of the leftover raft bits make base-adjacent pieces mesh together more solidly, and each pair being slightly thicker than designed makes the model stay assembled much more strongly than the minimal friction offered by an ideal print.  I have to throw the ball at the wall exceptionally hard to make it break into pieces.  I love this model!

title: Ultimaker 3 Drybox
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I finished my Drybox for my Ultimaker 3 using the original spool holder with the NFC function and some additional storage for two more spools.

I used some designes so I first want to give credit to:

@UltiArjan
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1837907
I used his dehumidifier basket but I had to modify it to fit my dehumidifier.

@T70E
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2559491
I used his Ultimaker 3 Spool Holder Bracket. He did an awesome job, I used it as it is.

The parts you need:

  • The box is a 'Orthex Clipbox Smart Store Classic 31' with 50 x 39 x 26 cm
  • The dehumidifier is a 'Pingi LV-A300LC' and is normally used in cars. It is rechageable.
  • 4x angle sheet metal to support the partition boards
  • 2x PVC board (8 mm) with ca. 40 x 8 cm (I'v sawn them off on an angle of 85°)
  • Strong double sided duct tape (I used '3M VHB Tape 5952F')

Q&A:

  • Why is there a base under the spool holder?
    -> The bottom (or now the back) of the box where the spool holder is mounted will bend when the front of the spool holder is not supported by a base.

  • Why don't you mount the spool holder deeper to avoid using a spool holder base?
    -> When you load/unload a spool you need to pull up the front part of the spool holder.
    Therefore you need space below. The base of the spool holder is not mounted. It's just sitting there.

  • Why is there just a hole and no filament outlet?
    -> I first did some outlets but the filament is on a high angle at that point and it was jamming.
    I think that the Dehumidifier is able to handle that little leak.

  • Why do you use two PVC boards instead of one big board?
    -> I don't want to seal up the two parts of the box.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

10%

title: Prusa i3 MK2/MK2S/MK3 Webcam (Fish Eye) support and Strain relief

description.text:
I mixed together various 'things' I found on Thingiverse and created this universal support platform. Credits to the original designers!

This is a support platform to fix various 'things' to your X-motor and acts as strain relief for the X-motor cables as well. Since it is attached to your X-motor, it moves up and down with the Z-height. It is a universal platform meant to fix Webcam's but maybe you'll have another use. I have added two designs for Webcams:

  • one for a Fisch Eye / Wide angle Raspberry Pi camera
  • one for a Logitech E35 camera

If you have another camera; you can easily design a fixture yourself, a plain support design is included as a starter.

The platform can be screwed with a spare M3 bolt/screw directly onto the spare hole on the X motor. You will need two M3 6mm screws / bolts to screw the camera support to the platform. The cables coming from the X motor can be secured with a zip-tie to the strain relief.

title: 2.5D Simple Chair and Table
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Let's imagine a chair laying on its side. That way we can draw it nicely with inkscape.

The side of the chair is duplicated. Both have 'height: 6mm', but the copy gets an additional 'raise: 40mm' attribute.
The darker part forms the seat and the back of the chair, it has 'height: 46 mm'.

The legs have that curved inner shape. This should make it easier for your 3D-Printer to succeed without support. chair_csupp.stl has a 0.8mm fin in the center that should server as support between left and right leg. Break away after print.

chair.svg was drawn with inkscape.
chair.scad and chair.stl were generated with https://github.com/fablabnbg/inkscape-paths2openscad/releases

chair.svg also contains a layer called 'laser'. The parts there should be cut from 4mm plywood, and when assembled, will form an identical chair -- just with a different process.

description.text:
This is the cover for the creation of an IRBlaster with a wemos D1 Mini (an ESP-8266 based board) based on the fantastic library IRremoteESP8266 (https://github.com/markszabo/IRremoteESP8266). The amazing thing about this project is that it will make you control everything that is IR-controllable using WiFI from another room and, if you are quite experienced and know how to open Router's ports, from every part of the world. With this IRBlaster you can also control your devices using MQTT and make them part of your IoT world.
IMPORTANT!: I'm a newbie with CAD, so there could be imperfections. The holes for the leds on the top and the space for the Wemos in the bottom part are very strict because I didn't want to use glue to fix leds and the board so you have to press a lot to insert leds and Wemos. In "Thing Files" you can also find the .step CAD file I made with Fusion 360, feel free to modify it!
The steps to make the IRBlaster are very simple and require only a little bit experience with soldering iron and Arduino to program the board. To make it simpler, I made here (https://imgur.com/a/ZkcW5) a photo guide including the schematic of the wiring.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.15

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Use supports as suggested. Set it to "Everywhere".

BILL OF MATERIALS

-Scissors
-Soldering Iron
-Soldering flux (not essential but i suggest it)
-4 NPN transistors (I used the popular PN2222)
-4 IR leds (I used the model IR333-A, very powerful)
-1 Wemos D1 mini R2 (works with both rev 2.3 or 3.0)
-Wire (I used a 25AWG one)
-Glue to stick top to bottom
Refer to the Summary and https://imgur.com/a/ZkcW5 for step by step guide.

description.text:
These wheels are for the Open RC Tractor by Makit (https://www.myminifactory.com/object/openrc-tractor-26360)

If you don't have any flexible filament for the wheels, and don't want to get any, than these files will help you. The tires do not fit on to the rims without a flexible tire. You can try heating up the tire to fit on the rim, but without a heatgun this will be very difficult. I just combined the tires with the rims on Meshmixer.

Warning; Printing time exceeds 16 hours on the back two wheels, and 3 hours on the front two wheels. PRINT AT YOUR OWN RISK. Support material is not needed on the front wheels, but the back may need some.

title: G2s Pro E3D V6 Maxmount (Now with BL-touch!)

description.text:
I thought that none of the stock effector E3D mounts available right now were not up to snuff, so I decided to design one! (And also see what Fusion 360 is capable of.)

REVISION 5 NEWS
See comments for the latest info.

UPDATE 2018-01-24
Version with M3 nut traps for fans added. (See notes for additional info.)
UPDATE 2018-01-16
BL-touch mounting version added. (See notes for additional info.)

Parts needed:

  • 2x 30mm fans. The E3D fans and the G2s stock "heatsink" fan will do fine.
    • Note: The fan mounting holes are made for the screws that come with the E3D fans. You can get away with using just 2 screws per fan.
  • 2x M3x10 bolts for fastening the halves together.
  • 3x M3x20 bolts for affixing the mount to the effector.
  • 5x M3 nuts for fastening the halves together and to affix the mount to the effector.

  • Obviously an E3D v6-style hotend.

  • For the BL-touch mount version:
    • Optional: BL-touch.
  • For the M3 fan mount version:
    • 8x M3 nuts
    • 8x M3x18 bolts.
    • OR:
    • 4x M3x18 bolts (for the lower mounting holes)
    • 4x M3x18-25 bolts (for the top mounting holes)

Disclaimer: These are the parts that I used, if you now what you are doing, you can use just about anything to mount the hotend and the mount to the effector. (I would advice against using industrial contact cement since that makes stuff....well, kinda permanent.)

Design goals:

  • Mount the hotend as high as possible to maximize z-height. (name->Maxmount)
  • Have adequate cooling even for >250C printing.
  • Have part cooling incorporated as neatly as possible.

Results:

  • The hotend is mounted 33mm higher than in my previous setup. (Your mileage may vary.)

  • The mount thrived through 45mins of 260C temperature without any changes, part cooling fan on, not on full for some reason. (Mount was printed in PETG, when I get the rest of the printer working correctly, I'll print and test a PLA one.)

  • Part cooling for 180 degrees of the hotend.

Notes:

  • The silicone sock is almost a must for any print that uses part cooling.
    Due to the "as sleek as possible" design goal, the part/layer cooling nozzles are right up to the heater block and could cool it down too much for any decent printing.

  • The thermistor and heater cartridge wires are supposed to go through a hole in the mount just left of the heatsink fan. (See pictures.)

  • You may also see that the model is too thin in some parts and your slicer won't create walls there. Those parts are placed in such places where they don't really matter when used as intented. (Example in pictures; the hole will be covered by the effector.)

  • The picture of the parts laying on the bed was taken hot off of the CR-10. 0.6 nozzle and 0.3 layer height with no supports. Not pretty but a few licks with a dremel and it works just fine.

  • UPDATE 2018-01-24
    Added version that has M3 nut traps for installing the fans without the E3D self tapping screws.
    I haven't tested this, but the nuts should be flush with the bottom face of the mount. If the bolts stick out much off of the fan bodies, they could crash into the effector arms. (There really isn't much space to work with...)

  • UPDATE 2018-01-16:
    Added a version of the intake side to take a BL-touch. Spacing is for normal V6. (As is pretty much the whole mount too...)
    When the probe is retracted, there should be 1.5mm clearance to the tip of the nozzle.
    I have not tested printing the part, but if you can add supports to only one place, it would be under the "front" BL-mount "arm". Though it wouldn't be the first insane overhang of this model that prints incredibly well...
  • The probe offsets are (also shown in pictures):
    • X: -31.3mm
    • Y: -18.1mm

TODO:

  • BL-touch flavor with M3 nut traps.
  • A Volcano version. Though I designed this for the express purpose of the stantard V6 as my Volcanos reside in my CR-10s where they get the most benefit. Leave a comment if you'd like one.
  • A chunkier up version, for those who want it to be perfect.
  • Probably would be a bit clumsy, but a version that takes 5015 fans too.

Printer:

CR-10 0.6 Volcano

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1-0.3

Infill:

15% / doesn't matter

Notes:

Should pring fine without supports. It won't look good, but it'll work.

description.text:
My RPG group has been playing a lot of Lamentations of the Flame Princess, and we noticed that we tend to respond to random encounters in only 3 ways:

  • running away
  • trying to set the monster/person/church on fire
  • trying to trick our way out of the situation

To save precious brainpower, I've created a die to select a random encounter response for us. It's a d6 with 2 copies each of flee, fire, and ſcam ("scam" didn't start with an "f" so I used the archaic long s for symmetry).

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/bMLldFIkrvd

author: Togusa

description.text:
This lamp is similar in shape to https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2508517 but uses different geometry to give it a more organic shape. This blog page describes the double twist method that creates the basic shape: http://birkbinnard.com/blog/do-the-twist/. Normally any STL file with overlapping shells will be difficult for slicers to slice properly, but this blog page tells how I was able to fix the overlapping shell problem with this (and other) STL files: http://birkbinnard.com/blog/problem-stl-files/.

This lamp printed in a little over 26 1/2 hours using a print speed of 80 mm/sec and a layer height of 0.200 mm.

This lamp is designed for an LED "puck" light. Battery operated lights are about $4 each; simply do a web search for "puck light". This blog page tells where you can get wall powered lights that work very well: http://birkbinnard.com/blog/wall-powered-led-lights/.

I used the bracket designed by egman17 and added a bottle holder to it. Designed for a 16.9 oz bottle. I used PLA at 35% infill. If she breaks it I will make it stronger.

Update, she has broken the water bottle holder once, the PLA is a bit brittle. I have swithed it to ABS and 50% infill for the holder. Seems to be holding up.

author: 3dp4life

description.text: for 45w power brick

This is a laser cut spool for holding 3mm filament. 
The spool is cut from 3mm Baltic Birch plywood. 
If you're lucky you can just use the PDF file. Alternately there are DXF files you can use, or tweak things in the OpenSCAD files if needed.

Laser cut two plates and six spacers.
Once cut you can assemble with a threaded rod.
Put the rod into a drill and spin it to load the filament. (The spacers have holes to thread & hold the filament.)
The plates have 3mm holes so you can tuck the filament into them to prevent unspooling when not in use.

comments.text: Hot glue held it all together.  The most challenging part was winding the filament onto the spool.  It held nearly 4kg of 3mm ABS.

description.text:
This is a camera clip to mount a 14mm wide FPV camera / transmitter module to a 20 x 20mm flight controller board stack as sold by BangGood. These are advertised as 20 x 20mm which is the mounting centres of the board. The PCB is actually 25 x 25mm.

There is a bit of an overhang in the print - Use support if you need to, or if overheating is causing the shelf to deform put the post in the middle of the arms in your printing software to slow down the print.

To fit, carefully slide the arms forward onto the PCB assembly using the blade of a small screwdriver to stop them catching on the components. Then squeeze to clip them around the far posts.
There's a slight lip on the flight board antenna guide. Use a small screwdriver to prod the antenna into the channel and it will stay there. The camera module is a tight friction fit in the holder.

title: Kossel base extension 40mm. BIQU. Delta. Legs, Feet

description.text:
I already had the kossel base printed and wanted extra height without wasting the current legs I had.

If using PLA i recommend you print the pins at 99% scale otherwise they can be to hard to get in and saves post processing time.

Quite simply, print the base which add's 40mm to the height, print the pins, slot the pins into their correct holes and slide the extension into the corresponding holes in the current base.

title: Baby Tux
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is an OpenSCAD version of the creation of Nicolas Rougier, originaly designed for POV-RAY (available at https://www.labri.fr/perso/nrougier/artwork/index.html#baby-gnu-and-baby-tux).
I had to modify the wing, tongue and feet to be able to draw it in openSCAD, I hope it doesn't change the spirit.

You can choose the position of the baby tux (seated or standing), and if the beak is open or closed (easier to print without the tongue). Choose the configuration using the coarse mode, and then refine the mesh before exporting. In fine mode, it can take a very long time (more than 1 hour!). It can be a multi-part model (one of each color or member), or mono-block (in yellow you get a nice chick).

I added 2 configuration directly in stl to save you time (standing, with beak open and closed).

title: Horizontal Universal Spool Holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a horizontal spool holder designed to use 608 ball bearings and imperial hardware. I designed this holder one to include a pin that threads into the middle of the rotor that can be swapped out based on the spool used. I've uploaded pins for Inland and Prusa PLA but it should be easy to modify the pins for other manufacturers. The pin and rotor use an M10x1.5 thread if you need to make your own pin. The ball bearings are mounted using 10-24x3/4" bolts and 10-24 nuts. The bushings are used to reduce the ID of the bearings to a close-clearance hole for the bolts.

You will need:

  • 10-24x3/4" bolts x3
  • 10-24 nuts
  • bushings x3
  • rotor x1
  • base x1
  • how many pins you think you need

Supports are needed for the base but should not be used for the pins or the rotor since this makes cleaning the threads very difficult.

Designed in Fusion 360

To set the printing I placed the smaller ring of the filter (GoPro lens side) on the bed of the 3D printer because when I tried to print it in other directions the result were not good, especially for the threaded part.

description.text:
3S Lipo Battery Holder designed for an SK450 quadcopter frame.

This is designed to better position the underslung battery on an SK450 dead cat quadcopter frame. The positioning of the screw holes allows it to be move fore-aft to adjust center-of-gravity (CG).

The hole sizes will fit M3 a little tight - probably better to use M2 or M2.5.

Update:

  • Had a slight issue with the strap ears on the rear tray breaking, so I made them thicker and printed it slower at 230C for better layer adhesion.
  • Since the part was printed in ABS, I acetone vapor treated both the front and rear tray which seems to have strengthened them significantly.
  • Added a center slot on the mounting ears for both parts for more versatile positioning.

Notes:

  • This design is not yet tested for real flight but the battery fits perfectly.
  • The length of the front "box" is a bit deep, and maybe a later version will be shallower as inserting the battery at a slight angle due to the cables is a little snug.
  • The battery holder surface and the mounting "ears" are intentionally offset slightly for a bit better strength.
  • The front interior surface is angled slightly as my battery cables come off the front right of the battery - which makes the front of the battery a slight wedge shape. I wanted to support the battery instead of having pressure on the cables with any forces going forward (like when I crash nose first taking out the camera gimbal and everything in the front of the quad).

Future Update Plans:

The slots seem a little long for the standard velcro strap. I may reduce the length a few mm.

title: Kossel Pro BIQU Cable support arm. Fits any 2020 frame without screws

description.text:
My BIQU Pro has no cable support at all for the cables that run to the head. The cable tidy kept catching on the side of the build platform and im sure it is the cause for some layer shifting.

This is my solution. Prints in two parts and simply slots together. You don't even need a screw. The block has a turn key type of fixing that you slot into the 2020 extruded frame and turn until it is the correct way and tight.

Their are a could of small holes for a very small cable tie or some string to fix the cable to the arm. My cable bundle is around 7mm and fits perfectly into the clip but if yours is to loose and you don't have very small cable tie, simple use a bigger one around the entire arm.

I used ColorFabb HT for both the heat resistance (as it is close to the hot bed) and its durability. PLA should work but make sure it is from one of the more durable brands. Ideally use either PETg, ABS, ASA or ColorFabb HT.

Push the cable support arm into the slot before fixing the block to the frame. The slot for the arm is tight but it will go in with some force. If you have issues either file the arm a bit or print the arm slightly smaller. If the arm is too loose, it will come out of the slot while the print head is moving.

Longer arm added, the shorter one just quite didn't do the job over time. The clip has been slightly tweaked to help account for an extra cable if you are running two cooling fans.

This design provides a piston type parachute recovery system for various body tube sizes for use with Estes model rocket body tubes. The body tube size is imprinted on the side of each piston. Though still under development, I have tested a paper and balsa wood version that worked quite well. The primary purpose is to assist in designing a parachute system based on a piston concept, eliminating the need to use wadding each time the rocket is launched.

A normal rubber band shock cord is attached to a bar on the underside of the piston, while the parachute cords are attached to the inside of the piston (possibly using fishing lure hooks). The shock cord must be attached below the area the piston must travel to provide clearance. Ensure sufficient space is available to fit the parachute(s) to be used.

Hope you can find this useful.

description.text:
This is an add-on accessory for the totally awesome Vorpal Combat Hexapod, If you haven't seen that yet, then this thing won't make sense, so visit there first:

  • Thing 2513566: Vorpal Combat Hexapod

I made this all open source and respectfully ask you to consider supporting the project. We successfully funded on Kickstarter with hundreds of kits sold, and now we have our own store. We have more than just the Hexapod electronics, we have all kinds of things useful for small robotics and other projects:
Vorpal Robotics Store with Hexapod Kits

  • IMPORTANT: If you opt-in to receive our store monthly newsletters you'll automatically be enrolled in a monthly prize drawing, first prize is a $100 store credit and there are lots of other smaller prizes too! Sign up for newsletters here:
  • Vorpal Store Opt-in for Prize Drawing

Why do I need this for the Hexapod?

This is a bracket that allows you to attach a panel voltmeter to the robot, allowing you to see your battery level very easily during activities. With this thing, you can know when the batteries are getting low very easily.

What Panel Meters Will Work?

The mounting hole is 15.5 x 23 mm and this is sufficient for commonly available panel meters.

The correct meter is available from the Vorpal Robotics Store

Preparation of the Panel Meter for Vorpal The Hexapod

You'll need to solder a male and female black jumper to the black wire coming off the voltmeter, and a male and female red wire coming from the red wire of the voltmeter. Some of these panel meters also have another wire, yellow or blue frequently, and this should be also connected to the red jumpers.

If you don't feel like soldering and wish to support our projects, we offer both kits and fully built versions of this voltmeter at the Vorpal Robotics Store

Mounting to the Robot

The bracket simply slots into one of the skeletonizing holes in the robot. run the cables through the top of the skeleton hole, mount the meter below it.

To electrically connect:

  • connect the meter's red male jumper to the red female jumper coming off the bec/switch assembly.
  • connect the meter's black male jumper to the black female jumper coming off the bec/switch assembly.
  • connect the meter's red female jumper to VIN on the Nano.
  • connect the meter's black female jumper to either GND pin on the Nano.

This puts the meter in parallel with the Nano, and it will display raw battery voltage.

This is and office sigh with a cross on the O of Office.
Size 180x80x2

description.text: Created this insert for the Jump Drive card game from Rio Grande Games. Cards, credits and exploration tokens often got mixed up and jumbled during transport. This holds the cards securely, and if you arrange the exploration tokens as shown, they hold the credits in place nicely.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

This is a long print. On my Duplicator i3 plus, it was upwards of 7 hours. You might be able to reduce this a bit by pulling infill down to 10%, but I ran a test version at 10% and there were some spots on the model that I wasn't happy with.

For mine, I was printing in PETG, which I still haven't quite gotten the hang of. Because of layer adhesion problems in initial prints, I left part cooling off until it got to the hexagons. Because some of the hexes require bridging, I figured that having some cooling at that point would help... and I think it did.

Jump Drive Box setup.

The interior of the jump drive box has a few cardboard pieces that need to be removed (or at least folded). Remove (or fold) any of the tabs that are in the bottom of the center section of the box. This should make exactly enough room for the insert to fit in.

Fusion 360, calipers and a couple test prints to make sure things would fit.

Since it's a long print, I don't know that I'll actively make changes to it, but a couple things I wouldn't mind changing:

  • fix the hexagon pattern: it's not quite even with the center of the big hexagon, and if you are triggered by stuff like that, it's something that will bother you forever. It kind of triggers me when I see it now.

  • add slots for the storage of the exploration tokens. Though this defeats the utility of the exploration tokens holding in the credit tokens.

  • Additional fillets on some of the edges. Really something I should have thought about before I printed, and now it's just a bit too late. You can easily get to all of the parts without ever taking the holder out of the box, so this is really really low on my list.

  • Get rid of the cardboard box completely. Create a nice deck/token carrier that I can just take the game with me. Yeah... this one sounds reasonable.

This is a motor mount I designed for the 3dlabprint Stearman Kaydet. The stock mounting design has you mount the motor to the very front of the "engine block". Unfortunately, that means the wires are up front as well, and must travel down the length of the "engine block" through the firewall. In my situation, that meant the wires would rub on the rotating housing of the engine. Not a good situation.

This motor mount allows you to mount the motor more traditionally, to the "fire wall". The mount holes were positioned for an Aeolean C3548 1100kv motor, but should fit others as well. I printed in ABS as I believe the strength is needed (it is a motor mount, after all).

In my particular case, I also had to provide some clearance to the engine block as well, so the motor mount bracket would fit, and the prop adapter could protrude out the end. See photos.

description.text: Simple window mounted bird feeder. Small songbirds love the easy food and it's nice to be able to get an up-close look.

Creality CR-10

Yes

25-40 percent

Notes:

Use whatever infill you feel is appropriate. I would suggest at least 25% but you probably don't really need to go much higher than 40%. All depends on how strong you think it needs to be.

Attaching your feeder

I used 3M wall adhesives on the back to attach the feeder to the window. This (so far at least) seems to provide plenty of adhesion. Another option is suction cups found at any hardware store. A small hole drilled near the top of the tower should be enough to allow for a suction cup.

Window Mounted Bird Feeder

This was designed in Fusion 360. The main tower component is a pretty basic series of circles, and extrudes. The base is an extruded circle with a sweep done to form the area where the seeds will fall into. The top is done much the same. Not an overly complicated design.

description.text:
This is a pretty obscure design but meets a serious need for me and hopefully others. It is a wind indicator for a small Hobie sail boat , using a carbon fiber arrow shaft to fly a streamer high above the mast. The arrow shaft is attached using an 8/32 threaded fastener embedded in the printed part. This makes it easily removable when you store your sail in the sail bag.

This part was designed on solid edge to address the need on the Hobie Island series sailboats for a good wind indicator. The Hobie wind indicator is poorly designed and difficult to see in certain points of sail. Since the Island series uses a roller furled main, you are unable to set the stock wind indicator to a position where it can reliably be seen. This design places the wind indicator high above the rotating mast making it visible in all sail/wind conditions.

I have used this sailing with great success but did not take any photos. I will add photos to this thing this spring when the water up here becomes less solid.

Printer:

Da Vinci Mini

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

15%

Notes:

This part created in Solid Edge. For some unknown reason, Solid edge creates .STL files in Metric using the number from the SAE design, using millimeters for inches. The mast cap should have a major outside diameter of 2 inches and the other components should be scaled by the same factor (25.4?)

Mast assembly

You may have to clean out the center hole of support material. Insert an 8/32 nut in the side slot lined up with the center hole. Thread an 8/32 fastener up through the part and the nut and tighten. For most arrows the 8/32 fastener will need to be at least 2 inches long to reach the threaded portion of the arrow shaft.

Arrow shaft. I used a standard carbon fiber arrow shaft and removed the nock and fletching from the end. The nock end is where you insert the shaft plug assembly (shaft plug, spinner and ring). I used a drop of glue to make sure it stays in. Thread the tip of the shaft into the mast cap. I was able to obtain the arrow shaft for free by visiting a local archery range and asking to rummage through their damaged arrows.

The mast cap is attached to the top of the mast with zip ties under the sail webbing.

print_settings.Notes:: DO NOT put in dishwasher since the plastic is likely to deform from the heat. Only clean with warm water and dish soap.

description.text:
Elsa, Anna, Olaf & Sven.

The outer edge cuts, and the inner details leaves an imprint in the dough.

Dimensions

  • Height: 10 mm
  • Imprint height: 7 mm

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0,25 mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Use PLA since it's rated as food safe, plus it won't warp.

The cutters varies in size but I've found that min. 14-15 cm in Y direction gives a good result. At that size the internal details prints nicely.
Scale them in your slicer.

The outer walls and bottom are 1,5 mm thick to give the cutter some rigidity.When slicing the model, scale z independently so that the mold becomes 10 mm high. This is to maintain the proper cutting depth and bottomplate thickness

DO NOT put in dishwasher since the plastic is likely to deform from the heat. Only clean with warm water and dish soap.

Edge cleanup

There could be some minor stringing between walls. Cut/ peel off with a small sharp knife.

To create these, I used coloring book motifs that I converted into vector format. For this I used the free software Incscape but any vector graphics program works fine.
Google "character name coloring pages" to find suitable pictures to work with.

  1. Save the picture you want and import it into Incscape.
  2. In incscape, create a bitmap copy of the object.
  3. Trace the lines of the bitmap. Use threshold 0,0 to get thicker lines. Simpler pictures works best, you don't want crazy amouts of detail since the 3D printer most likely will not be able to print it properly anyway. Some cleanup of the picture might be required to get it right for 3D printing. Make sure the outer edge is solid.
  4. Save as DXF or SVG format. This might depend on wich CAD-program you're using.
  5. Open the file in your CAD-program. Add the picture to a sketch and create your cookie cutter. Experiment to find what's working best for your setup.

title: Speaker box for HiVi B3N (and others maybe)

description.text:
.13CUFT speaker cabinet for a HiVi B3N speaker.

Roughly based off the Zaph Audio cabinet here: http://www.zaphaudio.com/audio-speaker18.html I changed a couple dimensions to better fit an 8x8 bed, but the internal volume is pretty close to the original design. You may want to build the filter he recommends on his page.

These sound surprisingly good for what they are. If you can cross over to a sub around 120hz you won't be missing anything. Or you could turn the volume down and give it a bump to the bass and use them as near field monitors. They can play low or loud, but not necessarily both. Either way, they do want quite a bit of power to run. I do suggest doing the filter from Zaph. There is a little harshness on the high end (breakup at 8khz) that is distracting without it. These things project really well and have no problem filling small/mid sized spaces with clear audio. Soundstage is pretty good and in my room extends beyond the speakers a few feet. I used 18% infill, put a bit of foam in the back half and very lightly filled the rest of the box. I didn't have any noticeable ringing.

Printer:

Fogertech 2020

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

3mm

Infill:

18%

Notes:

Infill as much as you want. The more the better, but it will eat a lot of plastic.
You will have to line the walls with some foam or otherwise stuff the box to prevent ringing.
Be careful with the screws on the back. If you miss the screw hole but try to screw it in anyway, it has no problem making its own path. But the halves will not be aligned and wont seal well.

Have fun!

print_settings.Notes:: I printed this with a shell thickness of 4mm instead of the usual 1.6mm. This gives a "solid" part which tested as the strongest versus a 100% infill on a thinner shell. This may be entirely due to other print settings, or quirks of my particular printer. I'd love feedback from makers trying different methods and materials.

title: 24mm socket for pentastar oil filter housing Jeep JK

description.text:
This is for all you makers that don't have a 24mm socket handy to change the oil in your Pentastar Jeep. A box end wrench or large crescent will work if you don't mind going 1/16 turn at a time against the drag of your old o-ring, but this makes it a little easier.

V1

1/2" drive tested in PLA and was able to torque filter housing to spec (25 N·m /18 ft. lbs.) as well as break it free initially without breaking the socket. In destructive testing the PLA version failed at 28 ft. lbs. You may want a large crescent to "start" your cover depending on how long it's been since it was last removed.

V2

Thicker (stronger) version with combo drive for 3/8" or 1/2". This will be stronger at the cost of a longer print time and more material used. Destructive testing will be done shortly and results posted... RE-UPLOADED w/ fixed scaling - Thanks for the feedback :-)

Printer:

Notes:

title: CR-10 Raspberry Pi Zero W Mount

description.text:

On my printer it was possible to power the Pi Zero directly from the CR-10's USB-port. (My printer is a CR-10S 40). You will need a Micro USB OTG cable, see one of the pictures.

You will need 4 button head M2.5 screws and 8 nuts to mount the Pi to the print.

I use Cura to send prints directly to Octoprint on the PI Zero. It is a power fill combination.

This is the plastic piece that commonly breaks on Toyota Tacoma's that have locking fuel doors.

This is a very simple fix if you have a 3D printer.  I used both a makerbot and ultrabot to print the part.  The ultrabot had a finer resoultion so the part came out with a better fit.  The best way would be to first add a washer on, and then the cap, then the lock. Super glueing the lock and cap.  The washer isn't shown, but would be good to help prevent the plastic lock from catching on the metal housing.

title: CT'c Bizer Heat Housing for ABS printing

description.text:
Heat Housing for CT'c Bizer

There are a lot of impressive designs available here on Thingiverse, but I wanted to keep it simple and useful.

You can easily remove the doors by sliding upwards to have an open build space for use of PLA filament.
You can also use the hinge axis for fixing of fan shrouds for cooling when PLA printing.
Unfortunately you need to wait until I will start using PLA, ...or you need to do your own design work ;)

Hinges and Door Snappers are fixed to frame and doors by using screws M4 X 16mm, washers, spring washers and nuts.
For hinge axis I used screws M4 X 20mm.
For the Door Handles I used 3.9mm X 13mm self tapping screws.

The Top Cover frame is made by using 15 X 15mm rectangular aluminum profile and double sided adhesive tape.
Just quick and easy.
Cut the profile according to the acrylic sheets when you have finished cutting them.
And please consider the thickness of the adhesive tape, ...I didn't and now the gaps are not according to what I wanted to have :(

You may glue the Top Bowden Cover to the acrylic sheet, but mine is sticking very fine by just slipping in.
Use the support option of your slicer software or the "Support" file attached.
...or none, if your printer is able to.

All other parts are designed to be printed without support.
You just need to place and rotate them accordingly to your build plate.

To get the holes drilled in the right position, please use the attached drill templates.
Please place holes for Door Handle and Snapper on your own, according to the results of your cutting and hinge hole drilling action.

Acrylic material thickness is 4mm.

If you want to order the acrylic sheets cutted to shape, use the STP files to send to your supplier.

Have fun!

Printer:

CT'c Bizer

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0,2mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

You may need support for the Bowden Cover part.
Please decide on your own.

At my work the credit card machine paper rolls are to big for the machine so we have to split them all in half, so I came up with this to save time and finger pain.. Its far from perfect but it works.

pertinent information

part 2 and 3 require supports, the other 2 are fine to print without any.

Make sure you are using the highest quality print settings you can especially on the bearings,

You have to free the bearings this involves beating the devil out of them until they are free, be careful of breaking other pieces while doing this.

the motion will be rough for a while until the machine is broken in.

Use your finger as a tensioner, or design one, I may do one in the future

you need to glue the handle on or shrink it a bit, I recommend gluing it though. you could also leave it off and use a power drill just don't go ham. ;)

While it is a complete as in the sense of being able to fulfill its purpose, I do plan on modifying it quite a bit.

title: Square Net Cup - 1.5 inch (36mm) grow cube

description.text:
This is a hydroponics net cup that doesn't require clay pebbles or any other grow media to support the grow cube. The grow cube fits snuggly into the net cup. This design leaves a large area of the underside of the grow cube exposed preventing obstruction to root growth.

It fits within a 3 inch (73-78mm) hole and holds a 1.5 inch (36mm) grow cube. I have other designs and intend on making more if requested. Please comment the size (hole and grow cube) that would be best for you and I'll make the most popular.

I've used this design for growing different things, with no problems, including:
-Chillis (in pictures)
-Giant Basil
-Coriander
-Various lettuces

I've found it's best printed without supports, as removing them usually results in damaging the net cup.

title: E3D Chimera or Cyclops Filament Cooling 30mm Fan Shroud
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I've designed this fan shroud to be compact, light and easy to install while allowing reasonably easy access to the heat blocks on the E3D Chimera and Cyclops extruders.
I printed both parts with PETG and bonded with CA glue. CA will also work with ABS and PLA. If you prefer a different material, be sure to select a compatible adhesive.
The heater blocks should be oriented as shown in the assembly model so the air stream from the nozzle can reach the print unimpeded.
After bonding the two shroud halves and installing your 30mm cooling fan, simply loosen the fan screws from the extruder's heat sink until they clear the shroud's bezel, fit it in, and tighten the screws.

Printer:

Banana 3D 330

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

<= 0.2

Infill:

70 to 100%

Notes:

1- The pictures show the parts standing on end, which is not the way they were designed for printing. They should be printed with their flat sides on the printer table.
2- Heater block "socks" provided by E3D with their chimera and cyclops extruders should be used to minimize heat loss from peripheral air flow.

author: ftaysse

description.text:
This is a remix from "Bike Disc Brake Protector" found on Pinshape (https://pinshape.com/items/22582-3d-printed-bike-disc-brake-protector) Designed by José Luis Garcia. I have copied it here for easy printing. His remarks are as follows:

Description
The design consists of 3 parts intended to protect your bike disc brake. The pieces are printed in PLA but you can print them in ABS.
You can use extension cords and longer screws to adapt it to other bikes and if it's necessary you can add a foam or rubber to fit all the pieces.
It's a simple design so you can modify it according your needs. I suggest you print the pieces in ABS first because it's a material more flexible and easy to handle.
If your bike doesn't have disc brake , you can use this design like a decorative element giving to your bike a racing appearance.
This design is the first prototype and you can improve it.
The print settings depend on your type of printer, I use Repetier-Host Slic3r SW. Config PLA.txt file is attached here. 

I've also added a version with a rotor shield. This one will likely need supports when printed as most of it is elevated.

comments.text: That was my original plan also but since I am building recumbent bikes, I ended up using non-suspended front forks. The pictures included by the original designer show what looks like a full suspension front fork, but I think the geometry of the fork tube to axle is not as standardized as one might hope. I found this was true when I was making disk brake mounts, where I ended up using the front mount for the rear and the rear mount for the front. I suppose I should have added that the disc brake protector is meant to be used with a 160 mm disk. That is most popular size, but by no means is it the only size out there. You may want to tell the original designer what modifications you make. I too am eager to see what modifications you make.

Designed to maintain cable messes, decrease the spagettification of cables on workbenches, cabling closets, around cable runs to clean up and make the area more manageable.

Designed in freeCAD

I ran excess cable during my cable run and absolutely hate cable ties, adding and removing cables from a cable tie run is more tedious in my personal opinion. Where I'd normally wrap everything around a screw on a nail in the wall zip tied into a loop, I wanted to see if we could get away without doing that. Due to the uneven lengths of my run I did have to print out a 3rd unit in order to have an even distribution upon plugging into the switch. For network expansion I may need to print out more, but to avoid those pesky zip ties I'll be happy. This way also allows for quick unwiring and rewiring if a new network standard becomes available.
