remixed_from.title: CR-10 3 in 1 Extruder Cover and Filament Guide

title: CR-10 3 in 1 Windowed Extruder Cover and Slotted-Filament Guide

description.text:
I printed and installed this awesome accessory by member graham01.
But I wasn't able to have visibility of the extruder gear or the filament especially when loading the filament.

Most often than not, I would forget to pass the filament through the guide in the Extruder cover. As a result, I would end up not using the cover because I would have to unload the filament and then reload it again, which wasn't practical especially after the printing had commenced!

Therefore, I modified this part with a couple of features to make it more usable.

The semi-circular windows on the top give me better visibility of the filament and the extruder gear specifically when loading the filament. The slots in the filament would allow me to slip the filament into the filament guide and put the cover on to the extruder (even when printing is in progress!).

These modifications have no adverse impact on how the filament is guided into the extruder while at the same time it's easier to load the filament.

title: Prusa i3 MK2S cooling fan nozzle upgrade

description.text: User PJR from the Prusa forums here, https://shop.prusa3d.com/forum/memberlist.php?mode=viewprofile&u=115 created a really good MK2S fan shroud design for the Prusa i3 MK2S. It wasn't uploaded here and I wanted to share with everyone

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

25%

Notes:

Infill isn't really necessary. If you are using simplify 3D, please manually add your supports, as the automatically generated ones will put some support pieces on the inside of the duct even if you select build plate only. This needs supports around the two side duct exits, and the little nub on the right side. When putting supports on the nub, try to place them as far away from the wall as possible so S3D doesn't place supports inside the print.

I printed using ABS, do not use PLA, it will melt and drag on your prints. If you use ABS, the top will be bridged. In S3D settings, make sure your fan turns on 100% during the bridge, and I reduced my print speed down to 30% and it printed fine.

This is an amazing upgrade and works better than the two duct exit solutions on here IMO. Honestly this solution is almost too good in some cases. You might find you need to lower fan speed on some prints haha. All credit goes to the forum poster.

title: Anycubic Filament Spool Holder Brace V1.5

description.text:
Updated to V1.5, see Version Updates section - model is now customizable

Since I got my Anycubic Kossel Delta (pulley version) recently, the need for quite a few upgrades came up.

I loved the fact the Anycubic added a nicely designed acrylic spool holder to the kit but it has a caveat that needs to be adressed: The metal rod to hold the spool in the holder is too small versus the inside spool diameter so that the spool sits on top of the rod. When the extruder tries to pull some filament, it pulls as far as it can until the spool gives way a few centimeters and the process repeats which results in uneven extrusion.
Hence the idea to design a brace to insert into both sides of the spool with centered bearings (standard skateboard issue bearing).
I added the SCAD file for your convenience :).

The print uses about 12g (0.42oz) / 3.96m (12.99ft) of filament per brace and according to Cura the print takes about 52 minutes with the print settings mentioned below but realistically will be more like 40 minutes.

For assembly you would need:

  • 2 standard skateboard bearings (Z608 I believe)
  • the above mentioned amounts of filament
  • a rod of some kind (8mm / 0.315in or less thick, at least 13.2cm / ~5.2 in long, better 1-2cm / 0.4-0.8in longer), wood, plastic, metal etc. - ideally 8mm to fit nicely into the bearing but smaller should do also since the spool is now nearly centered and should unroll more easily - initially I used a chopstick because I did not have a fitting rod yet, worked fine

I made the opening on the back of the brace a bit bigger so that the bearing can be pushed out more easily (with the back of a pen etc.) in case one wants to reuse the bearing.

This is a work in progress and there will be follow up versions but it can be printed as is and already provides an improvement.

Planned Updates

For version #2 I will add:

  • small braces to hold the rod in place in the holder
  • spacers for the spool to keep it centered in the holder (the holder is designed to hold bigger spools also so it would be good to keep the 1kg spool in place somehow)
  • I might try to add small tabs where the bearing goes that press agains the bearing so that the bearing stays in place even if it is removed a few times and the fit gets less snug
  • see if I can reduce the material demand even more (even though 12g is not too much to begin with I think)

Maybe version #3:

  • make a lying down version, for that I would have to reverse the position of the bearing holder and would need some kind of stand or holder to put it on top of the printer but I worry about the filament twisting too much because of the odd position towards the extruder

ps Images and print quality are still in the works :)

Let me know in the comments if anything is missing or if you have improvement ideas.

Printer:

Anycubic Kossel Delta (pulley version)

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I printed mine in PLA but it should work with other materials also.

It is designed for a snug fit between the spool and the brace so it is a good idea to have a calibrated printer but since the spool is plastic (which gives a bit when pressed), this should not be too critical.

Print settings:

  • resolution: 0.2mm
  • first layer print speed: 15mm/s
  • print speed: 50mm/s
  • infill: 20% infill
  • installed nozzle: 0.4mm nozzle
    Which gives around 52 min of print time (according to Cura, I did not time it yet, I think it took a bit less than that). I recommend slic3r though since it handles the walls etc. better (and has more infill options than Cura).

If you have the time, you could print it at 0.1mm layer height for extra smooth finish & precision.

First OpenSCAD design

I used digital calipers to measure the inside diameter of the spool and designed the brace in SCAD. I tried to reduce the needed amount of filament, i.e. initially the brace bottom was completely filled but I changed it to 4 centimeter-wide struts which provide more than enough stability considering the weight forces on it are very small (I could even try to reduce the size a bit more but 12g filament is already pretty little - I will experiment with a few material reduction ideas in later versions).
When measuring the inside diameter of the spool, I noticed that it was about 59mm at close to the outside and 58mm on the inside so I chose 58.5mm as a diameter to provide the mentioned snug press-fit for the brace.

UPDATE to V1.5

  • while I was playing around with the .scad-file and reading the manual I found the customization options and did a first round of parametrization of the brace
  • for now you can edit two fit options and a handful of size and looks options
  • If you like, have a look at the source code, it is very well documented (I probably overdid it a bit here ;)), just open the OpenSCAD file in any text editor / word processor or OpenSCAD itself
  • to use the customization options, you have two options: a) use the customizer here on thingiverse (Thing Apps Enabled -> Open in Customizer) or b) download one of the development snapshots of OpenSCAD (further down on the download page of OpenSCAD), then go to Edit->Preferences->Features->Customizer, check the tick box, and then uncheck View->Hide Customizer. Once your are satisfied with the settings, export as STL and plop it into your favourite slicer (Cura, slic3r, etc.)
  • if you open it in a development version of OpenSCAD you have another very helpful option (not yet available in the thingiverse customizer): you can enable and disable the different parts (colored parts) so that you can export for example only the bearing holder to check your fit settings (then adjust the settings, export again etc. and print several versions of it to see which fits best. Once you found the right size, enable the other parts, export and print the whole thing)
  • the whole source code (.scad-file) is now probably totally over-engineered but it was a good exercise for me to learn how to implement the customization options and to learn OpenSCAD in general. Since I documented the source code (almost too) abundantly, you might learn a thing or two as well if you want to get into SCAD
  • later edits will add working chamfer / bezel options to the brace wall and bearing holder so that you can adjust the fit / insertion some more

WED, January 17th, '18

  • after a bit of testing: so far am happy with the design, printing / extrusion is indeed much smoother now
  • experimented with slic3r as alternative to Cura, will stay with slic3r for the moment. It has more options for infill and handles the details better (for example if two traces are too close together, it combines them into one so that the printer just extrudes more material to make the trace wider, Cura would indeed try to do mini-zig-zag patterns as infill even in such a situation)

MON, January 15th, '18

  • 2nd brace is printed
  • fitting 8mm (plastic) rod in place and bearings lubricated with lubrication spray (Carfit Professional brand, got it for 3 bucks at a local super, WD40 or similar would do fine too): the spool now unrolls at the slightest pull, success :)

ToDo - Design

  • braces for holding the rod in place in the spool holder (not really necessary but gives a cleaner look and more stability so that the rod can not wiggle in the holder)
  • spacers to center / fix the roll a bit more
  • make the chamfer / bezel parameters functional

ToDo - Build

  • cut the rod to size
  • add spacers and braces to holder when finished

title: Many Formicarium 2
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Note - I have not tested these as I no longer have ants, but I made them a while ago and wanted to get it uploaded. I made these as more of a base to be easily modifiable, so there may not be what everyone is looking for yet.

Since my first many formicarums was kind of popular, i had started making more a while ago, and I sort of finished them so i should upload them before i forget again. I should say i don't have any ants anymore, so i haven't printed many of these, just tests to make sure they work. I started because I liked the design of the ants Canada formicarum with the holes at the bottom, so i made an easily printable formicaurm inspired by that, along with some other designs.

 Notes - I need a better picture, I just haven't wanted to print another. I printed a 
 different one before, and some other tests I lost, so everything should work fine.

 I will add a couple more examples soon, there are only 3 "sets" now, the one in the 
 picture, one with 4 blanks, and a circle grid one with 2 chambers.

 The Size diagram has a 4x4 on it, but i havent made one yet.

The files not in zips are just for display at the top!

I designed these to be easily modifiable so anyone can make their own interior design, and position of connectors. I've written a readme with detailed instructions anyone should be able to follow. The program I use is Microsoft's 3d Builder, It comes preinstalled with windows 10 so most people should have it already. For the interiors I just used paint. Hopefully some people will make some and share.

 Note - Because of this all the chambers have connectors on all sides. They are meant to 
 be taken off on sides not needed. If you really don't want to edit the chambers to 
 your liking there are sets in the examples zip.
Examples

The chambers I designed. Meant to be printed as sets, but you can do whatever you want. Use these if you really don't want to make your own.

The bottom water chambers and lids are also in this zip

Accessories

End stops, tube connectors, and more.

For Tube Adapters, 8mm works with 5/16 OD, 9.6mm works with 3/8 OD.

Proto

This is everything you need to design your own chambers. I really recommend at least trying. There is a readme with a detailed tutorial on how to edit the chambers.

Quick description on designing your own

What I really mean by designing your own is editing the chambers I made, by removing connections you don't need, and/or drawing an interior in paint. All you need to do is:

-Decide what size chamber, or combination of chambers, and grid type.

-Draw an interior on one of the premade templates. Than import and resize it.

-Remove any connections you don't want, and subtract the holes for the ones you want.

-Remove the corner piece for any exterior corners.

-Done

Bottom Grid

Inspired by the Ants Canada formicaruim, there are several sizes of water chamber to go below the formicarum. The holes should print fine on any setting. I set them further apart than I originally wanted so they print better, but there are my files if someone wants to try to print them closer together.

Version A has supports on the inside, Version B does not.

To Use, fill the back side with cotton or another material, and add water.

Circle Grid

A circle grid, Should work the same as the side grids. These will need a hole drilled in the acrylic. For drilling the acrylic use the lid as a guide. I recommend spade bits for acrylic and plastic.

19mm is 3/4, 22mm is 7/8 25mm is 1 inch. All of the premade chambers use 19mm except the 2x2 C and D.

Side Grid

Will make soon probably

Changes from other formicaurms

-Sizes are different from common sizes87 c. The 2x side is the same. (The 1x side is slightly smaller than the old ones.)
-Connector corners are square. (Seals better)
-Connectors have a top on the female part. (Looks and stays together better)

Things to be done

-Make more examples
-Add a side or connector for a heat cable.
-Add a side with a grid like the xl of the first many formicarums.
-Print some more for pictures.
-Make bigger water chamber.
-Make step downs better.
-Maybe 4x4 or bigger.

comments.text: Yea, its meant to be filled with cotton. Its inspired by http://www.antscanada.com/shop/formica-hybrid-nest-2-0/ (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=g1wzWGmZXhE), by Ants Canada. The problem I had with the small cotton areas on the side is they needed watered every day. I haven't actually tested it yet but it should work.(I've been busy and no longer have ants). Maybe I should make a half size one too?

Its not my idea, but a lot of formicarums use a similar system (It should work similar to concrete bottomed setups). That being said, I'm not sure that mine actually does work, so use at your own risk. (Im going to change it to WIP until I test and finish it)

remixed_from.author: SparkieDave10
remixed_from.title: RepRap Discount Smart Controller to Melzi Adaptor PCB

description.text:
I have an original, very old Wanhao Duplicator i3. From the first pre-order old. I have been working on updating the software, by installing a newer version of Marlin (thanks, Nitrogen777 ((https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2450111))). In the process, I toasted my display, via electric shock, and the only drop in replacement was $45 from some specialty website. No thanks, The RepRapDiscount Full Graphics Smart Controller is surprisingly similar, and runs for about $10.

After poking around, trying some other guides, I eventually just tested the pins, and found someplace on the back of the original board that they went, found the similar place on the new board, and wrote down what pin that was. Eventually, I mapped all 10 wanhao pins to pins on the 20 EXP1/2 connectors.

Attached is a PDF with the corresponding pins. Here is a description of the titles:

  • Pin Name: The name in the RepRap schematic that this pin is for
  • Wanhao Name: The name printed on the (not exactly a) melzi board. See the grainy picture I took.
  • Wanhao Pin: The pin number on the melzi/wanhao board. If you're unsure of which pin is pin 1, 2, 10, etc, look at the Wanhao Names compared to the connector in the picture.
  • EXP1 Pin: The pin on the EXP1 connector of the RepRap Display
  • EXP2 Pin: The pin on the EXP2 connector of the RepRap Display

I'm very sure the RepRap SD card won't work. I'm also sure that this isn't the same pinout as the standard melzi board. If you are trying to flash Marlin, then the pins_.h file can be found in the thing above by Nitrogen777. If you still have the original wanhao firmware, then this should work out of the box.

As I mentioned, I have the very oldest version of this printer. If you have a v1.1 or a plus, or v2 or whatever, there's a good chance this will be different. Let me know if this was useful.
I add the letters and caracters to the original PLA one.

Creality CR-10

No

0.1

10%

title: MPSM V2 Improved Extruder (WK9)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
WK9 Extruder

MPSM V2 Extruder Replacement.

Wiley Kyoto

This is an upgraded extruder meant to work with the MPSM V2 stock hardware (mid 2017 - Current). The only exception for parts are the Bowden tube fitting and bearing screw. Part of the reason to upgrade is that the stock Bowden tube fitting isn't a standard part, so when it breaks you'll need an alternative. Also The stock extruder arm is prone to breaking where it holds the bearing in place. This extruder is meant to work with a PC4-M6 Bowden Tube Fitting and an M6 nut, to replace the weird stock fitting. This extruder is also meant to work with a 10mm long M4 screw, to hold the bearing in place. You can pick up a PC4-M6 fitting online easily and you should be able to find an M6 nut and M4 Screw at your local hardware store. The M4 screw could also be a #8 x 3/8" imperial machine screw.

Stock parts:

  • M3 Stepper Mounting Screws
  • Arm Bushing
  • Spring
  • Bearing (4x11x4)
  • Feeder Gear

Needed parts:

  • PC4-M6 Pneumatic Straight Fitting, for 4mm OD tubing.
  • M6x1.0 Nut
  • M4 Screw, 10mm long. (or #8 x 3/8" Imperial Machine Screw)

Notes:

  • I printed this with PLA (Hatchbox - Pantone Yellow C), 0.175 Layer Height, 1.05mm wall thickness (3 shells), 20% infill, no supports, no raft.

  • If you just want to print a replacement Arm, the only extra part you'll need is an M4 screw 10mm long.

  • The Extruder Cap (which holds the bearing in place) comes in 4 different tolerances, I
    recommend using whichever fits in the tightest, as it helps properly support the bearing. I used the .00mm tolerance version, and it snapped securely in place. You'll want to flip this part over in your slicer (top down)

  • The Extruder base has a 4mm hole leading up to the slot that takes the M6 nut. This is meant so you can put a small length of PTFE tubing (<20mm), cut with a V shaped point (when looking from above), so that it nestles in between the drive gear and bearing (without touching). This helps guide the filament through the extruder and will allow you to print flexible filaments like TPU.

Acknowledgements:
Shout out to robin7331 and his MPSM Extruder Baseplate V1 for the idea to make a slot for a nut to work with a PC4-M6 fitting.

comments.text: I was able to use this part on my MP Mini Delta as they use they come with the same (poor) extruder from the factory.  Thank you for the robust design
comments.author: downtown711

comments.text: Just back from the hardware store to snag a 6M nut, and it turns out it's too thick to fit in the slot.
comments.author: 3DPrintedWaffles

comments.text: The best solution is buying a steel M6 nut, but if you can't get out to the hardware store immediately, I'm attaching an M6 nut which is from a McMaster-Carr 3D model. I've printed it and it's a tight fit on the brass fitting, and wicked tight in the slot on this design, but it's a way to print threads for this design without having to deal with them being oriented the wrong way. Print the nut flat on your print bed with the smallest layer height that is practical (I used 0.04375mm with excellent results but I'm sure 0.0875 would work fine as well) and you'll have a nut that should work. It might require some sanding after the fact, or just sink it 0.1mm into the build plate in your slicer.
comments.author: 3DPrintedWaffles

comments.text: Is it just a little too big? It should be quite snug (if it's a standard 5ish mm thick nut it should snap right in). If it's close you could try carving a bit of a chamfer arround the openning. But if it's way too thick, something like a nylock nut, you would probably sacrafise the structural integrity of the extruder trying to gouge out enough space for it.
comments.author: 3DPrintedWaffles

comments.text: I've found that with a small enough layer height, an M6x1 thread isn't bad IF the axis of the thread is perpendicular to your layers, which wouldn't be the case here.
comments.author: wileykyoto

comments.text: I made this and notice a lot of clicking after installing it.  I think the spring tension was too high so I drilled a hole in the arms and ran a bolt to reduce the tension on the motor.  Premade holes would be a nice improvement
comments.author: dxk3355

comments.text: This was designed with the same dimensions as the stock extruder, so the the spring should be applying the same amount of tension. If you're experiencing something different it's possible you've got a stiffer/longer spring than the one I designed this for. That being said I'm not clear on where you're suggesting these premade holes should be.
comments.author: dxk3355

comments.text: Could be clogging too, I thought I had cleaned it out but I've been getting bad clogs the last few runs (before my stock bed wiring broke).  I put the bolt through the narrow part of where the two arms are.
comments.author: wileykyoto

comments.text: Oh yeah, clogging will do that. could be your printer runs a little cold, so the hotend is struggling to keep the filament melted as it's pushed through. I think if I were to add a tensioning bolt I would probably redesign the whole thing to better accommodate it. I'm also not a fan of how these extruder types twist the screw used as a pivot. Someday there'll be a better version.
comments.author: dxk3355

comments.author: gdramos

comments.text:
Most 3D-printer controllers have low-side drivers for their fans and heating elements. This means that the positive(+) lead of the fan/heating element always has a constant +24V or +12V and the negative(-) lead of the fan is connected/disconnected rapidly according to the percentage set by the g-code command.
Therefore, All you need to do is disconnect the positive(+) lead from the controller which currently supplies +24V and connect it to your externally provided +12V (via the step down); the negative(-) leads of the fans remain at their original location on the controller because that's how they are controlled.

author: gdramos

print_settings.Notes:: Printed in PET-G for gasoline and oil resistance.

title: Carburetor spacer for Briggs and Stratton Sno/Gard 62000 (Snowblower Hako 6009H)

description.text:
I have a Hako Snowblower with fairly rare Briggs and Stratton Sno/gard 62000 two cycle engine. Bought for cheap with carburetor problem. My attempt to overhaul original carburettor failed. Original diaphragm set for this carburetor costs about 100$! I've tried to make DIY diaphragms but no luck.
Finally I have decided to go with stock universal diaphragm carburetor for brush cutter. Here is a link to ebay (just for example, random seller)

Biggest problem with this carburettor was that it is a bit different. Wrong bolt spacing, wrong throat diameter, and worse of all - it needs to be mounted in position 90 degrees different from original carburetor and impulse channel is on surface of engine/carburettor.

I've took old carburetor, old carburetor spacer, new carburetor and a caliper and start drawing in FreeCAD. This is what I've designed. Most challenging was impulse channel design.

Printed in PET-G. Sanded inside surface then covered it in epoxy glue (for fuel resistance) then inserted upper bolts (M5 afair) with epoxy. It is designed to put between old carburetor spacer and new carburetor. Fits well, engine works like a charm, PET-G doesn't melt or deform (yes it does, see UPDATE 2).

One thing I did not manage is engine governor (see update below). Original carburetor has metal throttle valve that turns without applying virtually any force. New carburetor has different construction - it has throttle in form of drilled cylinder and internal spring (that is essential for carburetor, cannot throw it out). This makes turning throttle fairly heavy and governor has no strength to overpass its resistance. Governor is not working right now (see update below).

UPDATE

Just updated project files for another carburetor from chainsaw (Walbro WT series) that has brass round plate as a throttle that turns without effort. Not tested yet but seems like it should work with original governor.

króciec-gaznika-odsniezarki-v4-gaźnik-pilarki.stl - spacer for chainsaw carburetor
króciec-gaznika-odsniezarki-v4-gaźnik-pilarki-kółko.stl - lever (wheel-form) for chainsaw carburetor
króciec-gaznika-odsniezarki-v4-gaźnik-pilarki-nakrywka.stl - anti-garbage protective cap for chainsaw carburetor. It is bolted on top of the carburetor and protects against falling small particles or parts inside of a carb throat. It is near identical to cap from original carburetor. It should also work with brush cutter carburetor.

Interesting fact: many snow blowers doesn't have air filter. Seems like in snowy winter conditions there is no dust floating everywhere.

UPDATE 2

Ended up with this part machined by hand and MIG welded from scrap metal parts. There was no problem with softening PETG when engine was running. During work engine is cooled efficiently by its fan and flow of air/fuel mixture. It softens just after engine was running few minutes and stopped. Seems that internal heat comes out from engine mixture channel and mounting bolts. It rises temperature of bottom part of the printed carburetor spacer making it soft and deforming.

In conclusion:

part invention and testing process was very simplified by CAD and 3d printing. Although printed carburetor spacer itself was not suitable for real life work, it has proven that concept realisation is just working. Then it was very simple to make such part from metal knowing shapes, dimensions and angles.

Printer:

X3D CoreXY

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Infill:

80%

Notes:

Printed in PET-G for gasoline and oil resistance.
Inside of air/fuel mixture and contact surfaces was sanded and covered with thin layer of two component epoxy glue for fuel/oil resistance.
Designed with FreeCAD/Linux.

author: szalat

title: Modular Hobby Paint Rack - Small Wall Hanging

description.text:
Sixth of the modular paint racks to store and organize hobby paints. This one is a smaller straight section that is for wall hanging. I designed this to hold Vallejo or Reaper dropper paint bottles. I will be adding more shelf layouts to hold paints such as Miniataire, GW and others!

Capacity:

  • 20 dropper bottles (Vallejo, Reaper, Army Painter)
  • 16 Minitaire bottles

Dropper style bottles can be stored in the upright or inverted position. I designed it more for the inverted position as that is the way I hold my paints to prevent tip dry out.

You will need to print the following to assemble one unit:

One of the following:

  • LeftSide-WallSmall
  • RightSide-WallSmall
  • BackSupportBottom-WallSmall
  • BackSupportTop-WallSmall

Four of the following

  • FrontHolder-WallSmall-(bottle style)
  • BackHolder-WallSmall-(bottle style)

To attach the top back support I have added screw fasteners since it will be hanging on the wall. You will need two 6-32 1/2" flat head machine screws and nuts. These are readily available at most big box hardware stores. After assembly just put the screws in with the head on the outside and hand tighten till secure.

The hanging holes in the back are made to take #4 screws. Use wall anchors if not drilling directly into a wall stud to hang.

Luckily these pieces would fight on the print bed but if it doesn't on yours you may have to split them and glue the two halves together. Assemble with the tabs and slots. I would also suggest glue just to be safe in case you have to move it even though the fit should be pretty tight.

Hope you enjoy this and it gives you more options to tidy up your painting desk.

Other units in the series:
Large Straight - https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2531450
Small Straight - https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2549451
Inside Corner - https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2543779
Outside Corner - https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2588073
Tool Holder - https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2601038

Upcoming:

  • Additional shelves for more paint brands

Revision History:

  • 01/18/2018 - Added two new files for Minitaire paints. The new front holder FrontHolder-WallSmall-Minitaire.stl and a new back holder for the very bottom BackHolder-WallSmall-Minitaire.

Happy Printing!!!

Notes:

For best results print the part vertically with the port holes on the bottom, this will prevent any problems with the overhangs. I recommend printing with 3 wall lines so that there is no infill in the thin sections. I also recommend using a brim to prevent it from becoming detached from the build surface (I used an 8mm brim).

I printed in PETG because I plan to use this in the car, and it may get hot (this may warp if made from PLA and used in a hot car).

Rose Tico's Medallion, from Star War - The Last Jedi.

From the film's Visual Dictionary we know: "Rose's medallion is a stylized ensign of the Otomok system, representing Hays Minor. It is made of pure Haysian smelt, a transition metal with incredibly efficient conductive properties. It is the partner medallion of the one worn by her sister, Paige"

You can see in the picture that this medallion can be produced to be Paige Tico's medallion as well, so you have the complete set.
This model Medallion is 2-sided - details in both sides - so it can be worn "reversed".

description.text:
I wanted to give my son a NYC subway train to use with his other wooden trains but I felt 30 dollars was too much.
So I designed my own version of an NYC train compatible with other wood and magnet trains.

Since the train uses a 5mm magnet ball as the connector it can connect to other trains in any orientation.

The subway car and bottom are separate so that anyone or myself in the future could design a new top.

The magnets aren't installed in the picture above since they haven't arrived, what I did do was use some 8mm x 1mm magnets I had and used those for now so that my son can use it with other trains. I will post an update picture when the magnets arrive.

The first train is an SLA print the rest are PLA.

Printer:

XYZPrinting Davinci Pro

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

10%

Notes:

The only part that should need support is the bottom section since it has the magnet holder that sticks out.

The pins should be 100% infill, it will make them strong enough to not break with kids use. I also suggest a drop off CA glue between the pin and body.

The only thing I suggest after removing the supports is to make sure the area where the magnet goes is smooth so that the ball can move freely inside.

A small drop of CA glue between the magnet holder and the bottom is suggested to keep it together. Make sure the magnet does not get any glue as it is designed to be a loose fit inside and be able to rotate inside its holder to be able to connect to any train.

I started by grabbing one of my sons wooden trains and a pair of calipers and started modeling just the bottom section in fusion 360.

Once that was done I created the 2 pegs to attach the top and worked off of reference images of the NYC trains.

description.text: Model I took and meshmixed into a 4 colour print, worked perfectly fine on my Dremel 3D20 with the mosaic palette.

Sometimes the spool seems to grab the Craftbot hanger rod and get swung off center by the extruder, so I created this. By using a bearing on each side of the rod, the spool is supported and will not swing, but rotates easily. Spools with an ID from 50mm to 60mm should work fine - which includes all the eSun, Monoprice, and CraftUnique filaments I have. To adjust for the width of the filament loosen the rear bracket and slide it on the hanger. The spool can still be easily removed with this in place.

(4) of any 608ZZ bearing should work. Also needs (4) M3x20mm socket head screws and (4) M3 hext nuts.

In the picture of the back of the printer, the bracket nearest the printer is an earlier rev with "elephant ears". This prevented the smaller diameter filament spools from being removed with the bracket in place, so the newer one has "mouse ears" which still work fine to keep the spool from jumping the track.

I originally considered using the "CraftBot filament roller" by gdlzsilip, but I have the hood option on the printer which extends over the rear of the printer and did not have the needed clearance. Also, that still allows the spool to sway.

description.text:
This is my attempt at reverse engineering the combination lock created by UGears for their wood safe (https://ugearsmodels.com/safe.html).

I assumed their 4mm laser-cut plywood (or MDF), but a simple proportional resize of the DXF will adjust the plans to other thicknesses.

As I drew all components using only intuition and visual acumen, the code wheels and front dial need reworking in order to replicate the code tables displayed in the manual.

It should be fairly functional by now but as I don't have access to a laser cutter in the next few months in order to test it, I will leave it as it is so anybody can rework and integrate it on their projects.

As an assembly guide and visual aid you can Google for the official UGears' user guide PDF.

This is my version of the board game Sequence. I designed the sections to be a max of 205mm in any direction, so my AM8 (stock Anet A8 heat bed) could handle it.

You'll need to print two of each tile except the middle piece - a total of 9 tiles.
The chips come in a set of 30 with 1mm spaces between. You'll need to print 3 different colors of chips. The chip holder will contain up to 60 of each color.

There are 4mmx1.5mm recesses in the corners of each section to glue in 3mmx1mm magnets, but this is not required - you can simple glue all 9 parts together to form one solid board.

The recesses for the cards were designed around miniature playing cards from Amazon:
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B011TSTFKM/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o06_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1
The cards need to be glued in place, in an arrangement of your choice - you need two mini decks with the Jacks removed. You'll need two normal size decks (with Jacks - see ethe rules) to play with. The way I've designed this board, some of the cards will need to be cut where the seams are unless you plan to make a solid, non-modular board.

I made my own chips for the game, which I've included - you can also use any standard size poker chips.

author: ecodweeb

description.text: Since I built my Prusa Mendel, I've been looking for ways to get more light on the bed during printing. I finally hit upon this excellent solution. The idea is to install an extra frame vertex on one (or both) ends of the printer top bar; the vertex is enhanced to include a tab that supports one of these great gooseneck lights sold by Ikea. (Strangely, you can't/couldn't actually buy them on the Ikea web site, but you can buy them other places, e.g., here) Get two lights and put a mount on each end of the printer for even more light and less shadows. The long gooseneck lets you put light wherever you want it, and it's bright enough to let you see how the print is progressing without being blinding or totally obnoxious. You can run the light directly from your house power using the power adaptor that comes with it; I put together a simple 500mA constant current source so I could power the light from the printer's 12V supply (so everything turns on and off at once). Note that you can use the frame vertex that holds the lamp as part of this Prusa Mendel Filament Spool Holder to get a two-fer.

(1) Buy one or two Ikea JANSJÖ– lamps.  Get the kind that sits on a weighted base.
(2) Print one or two of the frame vertex parts from this page.  I used ABS, but the strength requirements are not huge so PLA would be fine as well, I'm sure.  Drill the holes that will take the threaded rod to 8.5mm; drill the holes in the mounting tab to 5.5mm.
(3) Mount the vertex on the end of the printer top bar.  Orient it so the flat surface of the mounting tab faces up.  Use the same nuts and washers you used to assemble the rest of the printer.  
(4) Discard the weighted base that comes with the lamp.  Mount the end of the gooseneck directly to the tab on the vertex, using the screws and washers that come with the lamp.  Position the lamp head as needed (I put mine so it's off to the side and out of the way.)
(5) Either connect the lamp to a wall socket, or else figure out some other power source.

print_settings.Infill:: 20 - 30% has worked fine for me.  You should consider more for 5000+ rpm's

title: Permanent Magnet Motor/Generator Rotor
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a permanent magnet motor or generator rotor. It uses a double stack of the popular sized ceramic magnets (1-7/8" X 7/8" X 3/8") like these :https://www.harborfreight.com/pack-of-2-ceramic-block-magnets-97504.html for each of the 6 positions. There is a choice of either a rotor for a 8mm shaft or a 1/2" shaft. Use #6 to 32 x 1/2" bolts to attach the ends. Dimensions: 3.5" diameter X 1.885" length. Also added .25" bearing stand-offs on both ends.
.01" added to spaces for magnets and bolt holes to compensate for shrinkage of material. I like to use a good polyester glue to secure my magnets. Gorilla Glue works great.

Disclaimer: Disclaimer: Experiment at your own risk. Catastrophic failure of parts spinning at high speed can cause damage to property, injury, or even death.

2/24/2018 I added a magnet cover for additional support. This should add some safety when spinning at higher rpm's. A better option would be a fiberglass or carbon fiber layer. This should also be accompanied with 100% infill on the rotor for high speed experiments. Also don't forget to glue your magnets in place. I like Gorilla Glue. It seems to handle shock and vibration the best. Make sure you use water or it won't set properly.

description.text:
Remote Controlled Arduino Car
by Kevin Mercer
http://www.KevinRMercer.com

Overview:

This Arduino car utilizes four continuous rotation servo motors to achieve quick, accurate movements and a tight turning radius. An infrared remote and receiver allow the driver wireless operation.

The car is designed to be laser cut from 1/8 inch (.125 inch) plywood or acrylic sheet. As all of its components are connected with finger joints, no glue is required; instead, the chassis is held together with four 3D printed clips. Additionally, the car requires twelve* machine screws and nuts, which are listed below.

The code is easily modifiable to adjust the car's speed, turning degrees, and continuous driving distance. Predefined actions include forward and reverse driving, 90 degree turns left and right, a 180 degree rotation, and a "dance". Additionally, the car is able to drive forward continuously until interrupted by a stop function.

Materials:

1 x Arduino/Genuino Uno Development Board
4 x Continuous Rotation Servo Motors (With Horns and Screws)
1 x Mini Breadboard
12 x 4 - 40 Machine Screws & Nuts, 1/2 inch (.5 inch) each
---Only 4 may be required if you 3D print each wheel, but at your discretion*---
2 x 12 inch x 24 inch x 1/8 inch (.125 inch) Plywood or Acrylic Sheet
1 x Rechargeable Power Bank
1 x Infrared Receiver & Infrared Remote
25 x Jumper Wires
2 x LED's (Optional)
4 x Rubber Bands (Optional)
Several Small Zip Ties
Command Strips or Adhesive-Backed Velcro

Links:

Development Board
https://www.amazon.com/SainSmart-Arduino-ATmega328P-Development-Board/dp/B00E5WJSHK/ref=sr_1_5?s=wireless&ie=UTF8&qid=1515902048&sr=1-5&keywords=arduino+uno

Motors
https://www.amazon.com/FEETECH-FS90R-Pack-Continuous-himalayanelixir/dp/B074BFQC3Q/ref=sr_1_cc_2?s=aps&ie=UTF8&qid=1515902076&sr=1-2-catcorr&keywords=continuous+rotation+servo

Power Bank
https://www.amazon.com/Aibocn-External-Battery-Charger-Flashlight/dp/B013HIR1Q2/ref=sr_1_1_sspa?ie=UTF8&qid=1515901925&sr=8-1-spons&keywords=power+bank&psc=1

Infrared Remote & Receiver
https://www.bananarobotics.com/shop/IR-Remote-Control-Kit?gclid=EAIaIQobChMIvpfu38zW2AIViaDsCh0lYArUEAQYAiABEgJsj_D_BwE

Tips:

-Program your laser cutter to cut the smallest shapes free first, then the perimeters of larger shapes. This will ensure that the details of a particular component are correctly placed prior to cutting out that component.

-The top and bottom panels are labeled T. and B., respectively. The lefthand outer panel is labeled L.O., and the righthand outer panel is labeled R.O.. All but the front and rear panels have arrows indicating their forward orientation. The front and rear panels are interchangeable.

-Lightly sand the servo-shaped holes with an emory board prior to installing the motors. The fit is tight, as it should be, but forcing a motor into place may crack the plywood or acrylic.

-Each servo is meant to fit in its hole only one way. You will notice a small notch cut for the servo's three wires. Note that only one screw is required per motor.

-Once each servo is fitted, you will need to enlarge the hole on its ''wing'' to 1/8 inch (.125 inch) large. The plastic is soft enough to drill by hand with the appropriate drill bit; exercise caution if you use a drill for this step as damage can be caused to the servo.

-Each wheel is comprised of three stacked 1/8 inch (.125 inch) layers of plywood or acrylic. An .STL of the full-width wheel is available for download if you would prefer to 3D print it instead. Should you use a 3D printed wheel, you will need to pre-drill holes for the servo horns. The provided servo screws may work for attachment, but two 1/2 inch (.5 inch) 4-40 machine screws per wheel may be necessary. Similarly, an acrylic wheel will require pre-drilling; a plywood wheel will not. Because of this, the plywood wheels are the easiest to install.

-Any cross-shaped or circular servo horn will work. Each wheel should only require two servo screws for attachment.

-If your car seems to get too little traction on slick floors, add a rubber band to each wheel. A 3 inch by 1/4 inch (.25 inch) band will work well.

-If your infrared receiver does not receive signals from odd angles, a second receiver can be added. This will require splitting the circuit in the same fashion as either the lefthand or righthand servos.

-Continuous rotation servos may require "zeroing". If a motor rotates when it should not, adjust the small Phillips screw on its bottom side until the motor stops rotating.

-Your infrared receiver should show three lettered pins: "G", "R", and "Y". "G" = Ground. "R" = 3.3v. "Y" = Signal.

-The provided .INO prints your infrared remote's hexadecimal codes in the serial monitor, so you can identify each button's corresponding HEX code. Use this to establish which buttons will drive the car and in what directions.

https://youtu.be/uCo3nz9ylbg

Printer Brand:

Afinia

Yes

No

.10 mm to .35 mm

13% to 20%

Notes:

The layer thickness and infill can be adjusted at your discretion, but I find that a little looser infill yields a more flexible clip.

A little denser infill will yield a stronger wheel that is better for pre-drilling.

Development

The chassis, wheels, and clips were designed in TinkerCad, which generated both .STL and .SVG files.

The fritzing diagram was drafted in Fritzing.
Finally I got to design a stand for my RTS and RDA, and I am sharing it for anyone to use. Enjoy..........

description.text:
This is a rendition of John Heisz's Compact Compass found here: https://ibuildit.ca/tips/making-a-compact-compass/

The two compass parts can be adjusted in OpenSCAD and exported as SVG or DXF for CNC, laser cut or template making. The compass shapes were cut out of 5mm plywood and the knob was cut out of 3mm plywood

Materials needed:

  • 10-24 x 1" Oval Bolt
  • 10-24 Nut
  • 6d Finish Nail

All pieces are ready to be cut in the LaserCut SVG. Check pictures for assembly. I also included all the individual exported SVG files for your convenience.

The main design is customizable so feel free to adjust for you needs. Simple and useful project. I ended up coating my final compass in some tung oil. Enjoy.

Nailed it Center Point Compass Piece

The 6d finish nail is bent at 90 degrees approx. 11mm from the tip. I actually chucked the nail in a drill and turned it against my bench grinder for a smoother point. This is put into place using epoxy. The engraved line helps keep it straight while curing.

Epoxy and the pivot bolt Pencil Compass Piece

I countersunk the bolt hole to better situate the oval head bolt I was using. The 10-24 bolt is glued through the pencil piece using epoxy. I left it hanging so it stayed relatively flat while settling. I countersunk the top of the pencil hole a little to add flexibility to the movement of the pencil.

Knob

The nut is placed between the sections of the three layers. I ran a bolt through these and tightened against itself while letting the wood glue dry.

Finalized pieces

description.text:
Notes:

  • I haven't flown the Reverie much, I love how it flies so far but I need to crash it a bit more to check durability.
  • The head weighs 16g when printed in TPU with 30% triangular infill. A Reverie with 235 4mm arms weighs 90g with hardware and 3D printed head. A Reverie with 260 5mm arms and 3D printed head is ~100g.

The Reverie is a freestyle frame derived from a variety of other quadcopter frames, namely:

  • California Quads FB-01(The 3D printed head, top/bottom plate style and 15mm body height)
  • XLabs Steez (235mm True X stance)
  • Hyperlite Flowride (Lingering Top Plate)

The Reverie comes in 5" (235), 6" (260) and 7" (285) arm sizes.

Videos:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TBbjuGPNyYw

Carbon Fiber Cutting Instructions:
All Reverie frame parts can be found ready to order on my Armattan productions store: https://armattanproductions.com/pages/designer_shop_grid/7628/393
(I use a 0% commission rate so my parts and frames are as cheap as possible)

  • 235 Arm: 4mm CF
  • 260 Arm: 5mm CF
  • 285 Arm: 5mm CF
  • Brace Plate: 2mm CF
  • Base Plate: 2mm CF
  • Top Plate: 2mm CF

3D Printing Instructions:
All Reverie 3D printed parts should be printed in a flexible filament such as TPU.

Reverie Head: 30% triangular infill / 0.2mm layer height (Important to ensure the slit prints correctly) / Supports enabled.

Reverie Arm Guards: 100% infill optimal / may need to be scaled depending on the accuracy of your printer.

Enjoy! leave a comment if you have any questions.

Note:
All of my designs are free to download, print and cut for non-commercial use. Producing a remix of any of my designs for commercial purposes is permissible as long as credit is given to the original design. Please contact me if you are interested in using any of my designs commercially.

description.text:
I started off wanting to make this a small weekend project, but I was wrong. Since I saw this contest I have been playing around with BlocksCAD for days. First I wanted to make a simple shaped snowflake, then a little more custom R2-D2 snowflake. After more consideration I thought, why not add more and more to it. The center symbols spin in a group and the small one in the center.

Here I have a video of the snowflake spinning in action. https://youtu.be/QhaKaAw_m2Q
You can check it out at BlocksCAD here: https://www.blockscad3d.com/community/projects/72980

Here I have an R2-D2 Snowflake with the Galactic Federation Symbols as well as a Rebel Alliance Symbol in the middle. I used an extensive amount of blocks and hours to make this come to life. I began with R2-D2, as that was my first idea. All my shapes were made with cubes at the very beginning, from the body to the head, I just removed pieces over and over to form a rounded shape. I realized that I should watch all the BlocksCAD videos to fully understand the program (Which I'm happy I did) only to find out I can make rounded cubes using the union block. From there I went ahead and created R2-D2. At first all of my code was in just one long set of blocks, but the video taught me more about modules and how to organize and separate my code. I asked my high school teacher to print it out for me and I have images of the print.

I have a few images of my snowflake printer. It is not perfect, there is some stringing and maybe have to calibrate the printer a little. Along with my print pictures, my code pictures from left to right show different groups of modules grouped together to from a part of the snowflake.

Code Image 1: Is the main control system where I can scale the object as well as change the number of sides for all my circular shapes. My uploaded file is set to 100 sides for more accuracy.

Image 2: Contains a lot of removal for the main body to cut out all of the pieces of R2-D2. Where I first began to make long cylindrical rectangles instead of just rectangles. There is a lot of difference Set Ops used, plus unions.

Image 3: This is the head, it took a little time to make the rounded, triangle like rectangles because they were a little different and making sure every piece lined up took some time.

Image 4: The Galactic Federation may have been the most difficult part of this entire project. I needed to use two loops in order to get this to work. At first I wasn't sure of what to put in the center of my snowflake so from here on out I used a test space/project area in order to test out what I should design and how to implement it before actually placing it in my main project. Afterwards I had to go back and implement yet another symbol and the spinning system.

Image 5: The Rebel Alliance also took me a little while to make, although after the Galactic Federation symbol, things became easier. I wasn't sure how to make an oval so I used a flattened cylinder in order to form it and just extended it.

Image 6: This is the bars for the spinning system and the base circle. I had to make a few test prints with a little cube to make sure it would spin and I found that these dimensions were perfect.

The rest of the pictures are images of the final design. The files are all with sides of 100 for the highest accuracy. Thank you for checking out my snowflake! If you have any questions let me know.
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/05jCvv119Ah

author: ecodweeb

description.text:
This Doodle3D tower is made for a children's movie festival in the Netherlands autumn 2013 called Cinekid. Rick [Doodle3D] and me wanted to make an autonomous 3D print installation for children. To make it a bit more fun we stacked the 3D printers a bit angled.
When printing we didn't print on the blue tape. We used paper sheets [200 grams] and 'just glued them with Glue stick on the platform or clamped them with a paper clamp. The instructions are printed on the sheets. For more info about my projects see:
www.rooiejoris.nl
www.facebook.com/europerminutedesign

Instructions
  • Laser cut the design and put it together like an Ultimaker original.
  • Place the the ipads under the would and mount them with rubber bands [used for tents]
  • Place the safety feeder gear wheel discs
  • Take a few steps back and watch children [and adults] having lots of fun.
    • To make the tower more stable it is fixed to a sheet of fake grass. This also keeps the adults on a distance and the children could sit on the floor.
    The electronics and chargers are all hided in the bottom and the power cord is hidden under the 'grass'. To make it extra stable, the tower is fixed on the carpet with an extra piece of would and bolts [this is optional]. When working with kids there are 2 [a little] dangerous parts on an Ultimaker. The hot end and the feeder mechanism gears. You can cover the hotend, but then you don't see how it works and in my opinion that is less fun. For the feeder gear i printed a safety disc so small fingers cannot catch between the gears. For more info about my projects see:
    www.rooiejoris.nl
    www.facebook.com/europerminutedesign

description.text:
I bought a kitchen knife from DAISO, but it doesn't go with sheath. To make it safer at storage, I decided to print a sheath for it. After searching Thingiverse, I cannot found any model fitting this knife, so I use Fusion 360 to design one.

I first took a picture of this knife and set it to the canvas layer in Fusion 360. I sketched its blade with special curvature. However, my first work cannot fit the knife well because of the spherical aberration.

The uploaded file is the 2nd version of this knife sheath, they fit perfectly. I also add a logo of my workshop.

description.text:
Miniature Portable Medieval Grindstone. Besides the portable grindstone with framework, there are miniature boxes and a basket. I have included a pike, an axe and a cleaver. One of the boxes prints with a knife and scraper as part of the box. One box is empty. The grindstone really does turn with the rotation rod if done right.
I thought about creating more items to be sharpened, but there are so many good knives, weapons and swords that can be printed and placed with these items on this site, I felt it wasn't worth the time. I also increased the size and have a picture of the larger grindstone which will go with my giants.
The holes for the rotation rod in both the framework and the stone will most likely need to be cleaned out. I made the rotation rod a little big to have tight fits. After printing you will need to file or sand down the rotation rod to your desired snugness.
The two top planks with holes are glued to the two supports with an overhang on one of the supports. The holes should hang down and inside the frame work. There are then two wood cross members that also need glued across the two supports to provide the final rigidity.

I purchased my dual as an upgrade, and didn't like the fact that the Right Side Filament Tube was held by one of the mounting screws on a stepper motor, (I'm kind of funny with motor mounts). My first version was built before i did my upgrade, and just went straight along the top plate and hung out far enough for the tube, but I realized while doing the upgrade that would interfere with wire loom.

So here is the newest design. Fits nicely on the top plate rail and holds firmly with one screw.

Print the inverted file, bridges over nicely.

description.text:
The Locust 4" is a lightweight (35g with necessary hardware and no pod) and rugged race oriented quadcopter. Optimised for cheap production, durability and compatibility. The Loc4 has a size of about 160mm motor to motor and uses an outer 40mm hole spacing, allowing it to be widely compatible with many Shendrones pods. I like to use the Skinny Screamer 40 degree pod with my Loc4. (The STL file for the Skinny Screamer Pod can be found in the Loc4 thing files. It is not my design and I take no credit for it. I have only uploaded this file to the Loc4 page because I am unable to find the original listing for the Skinny Screamer Pod on Thingiverse.) The pictured Loc4 weighs 196g with props on and no battery, this weight could easily be decreased by using different pods, a micro camera or a 4in1 ESC.

Carbon Fiber Cutting Instructions:
All Locust frame parts can be found ready to order on my Armattan productions store: https://armattanproductions.com/pages/kit_detail/1186
(I use a 0% commission rate so my parts and frames are as cheap as possible)

  • Loc4 Arm: 5mm CF
  • Locust 40mm/30.5mm Plate: 2mm CF

3D Printing Instructions:
All Locust 3D printed parts should be printed in a flexible filament such as TPU.

  • Loc4 Arm Guards: 100% infill optimal / may need to be scaled depending on the accuracy of your printer.

  • Skinny Screamer Pod: 100% infill optimal / Supports required

Enjoy! leave a comment if you have any questions.

Note:

Notes:

  • I've been flying the Jackal as an everyday freestyle rig and can definitely vouch for its durability. It flies very nicely although it is a pretty tight build, I've only just managed to fit an XSR, DYS Mi200 and a PDB+FC inside. I've broken a handful of zip ties in hard crashes, usually only one or two snap but sometimes I have been unlucky and accidentally ejected the GoPro, however it has never gone far from the quad.
  • The Jackal Bottom Plate SMA holes are too small and need to be fixed.
  • The HD camera strap slots on the slanted plate are too far back. In the pictures you can see I have been strapping the back of the GoPro and using a zip tie to secure the front. I will fix the slanted plate slot positioning soon.
  • The bare frame with all necessary hardware weighs 71g, The pictured quad weighs 394g with props, GoPro and no battery.

This is a docking station for the Smok G-Priv 2 box mod. It is a redesign of the G-Priv dock by Manta225. His design served as a good starting point in order to make some significant changes.

First, I tightened up the pocket so there is no slop when docking the mod.

Then I Increased the height so that I could use a beefier USB cable to power it. Personally, I use these cables from Amazon and they work great:

https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01ER9U3NS/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o07_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

I also snugged up the USB opening. The Micro USB connector will go in very tight but once seated, it is not going to fall out.

Finally, I crafted a method of inserting the cable and routing it through a holding area so that it's not loose and getting in the way. Personally. I dislike having to constantly pick up a device to reset where the cable is sitting. This takes care of that problem.

Happy Printing and Vape on.

description.text: not all bottles are the same, but this one should work for most. This design was inspired by Chris, and so it shall be known as the Chris balancer! If you have a particularly short bottle, you may need to keep the neck from going in all the way. If you find that it is not stable and want to adjust, for bottles wanting to tip left (as seen in my pic) you would want to make it shorter. The bottle in the picture is a taller typical riesling style bottle but a different (shorter) style bottle would benefit from dropping maybe as much as a cm. Alternatively you can just do like I already said above and not set the neck all the way in. I printed without supports and a higher infill like 40-50 i think, you dont want that main part to flex else it will alter the center of mass.

comments.text: No, I don't like posting STL files. I prefer to only post the (better) design files so that anyone can use the design. I mostly consider STL's worthless to post. I would however be happy to help/teach you to make your own STL. Start by downloading OpenSCAD, its free and its the software used to design this thing. Within this software you will open/load the file that I posted, and then you can compile your own STL and save it.

title: Airbrush Paint Strainer Filter
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is my airbrush paint strainer.
I uploaded two sizes: Large and 50% smaller. It consists of two pieces, the base and the insert. To set it up, stretch your filter material over the bottom of the insert (Thin cotton, old nylon stocking etc) and seat the insert into the base. Trim the excess filter from around the side (See photo).

title: SimplifyVR Ultra360 6-camera 360 Panoramic Video Rig for GoPro Hero4 Panorama Mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
We are slowly releasing all of the designs for our 360 rigs here on Thingiverse -- we have sold many but the market is slowing down for 360 rigs while our threaded inserts used in them are getting more and more popular. We hope releasing the STL files freely will encourage greater adoption of our designs, and we intend to continue supplying the inserts for the long term, and the COTS components for at least the medium term.

This is a 6-camera 360 rig designed for the GoPro Hero4. It worked well for us while we were based in Alaska. Now that we are based in Georgia (the state), we don't come across many scenes worthy of 360 photography :-(

This rig is waterproof - it uses the standard GoPro housings, and aftermarket backplates which enable the cameras to be mounted at a 90-degree angle. Here is the link to our eBay listing for this backplate:
https://www.ebay.com/itm/292388300909

You will also need a variety of threaded inserts -- which is now our primary product line.
These are available on both eBay and Amazon.
The corners use 1/4-20 (short) inserts, and each backplate mount requires one M5 short inserts and 4 #8-32 inserts (long). We are expanding our fastener catalog but for now we suggest buying fasteners from wherever you would normally buy them.
Our eBay listings are here:
http://stores.ebay.com/Albers-LLC?_dmd=2&_nkw=inserts
while our Amazon listings can be found by searching for "initeq inserts"

author: celiktse

title: Lightweight Frame V7 for E010 / Tiny Whoop
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a lightweight frame I designed for my E010. The frame alone weighs about 3.3g printed in ABS, and is very durable (PLA works as well). I believe it will also work as a Tiny Whoop frame replacement as well. A battery holder bracket is included (fits the stock E010 battery), and is to be super glued to the bottom of the frame.

Flight:
Updated flight characteristics - Without the FPV camera on board, flight performance is really good on this frame, using the stock E010 flight controller, motors, props, and battery. Especially fast in the high-rates mode. Flight time is pretty decent too. A higher capacity battery is definitely needed for using the FPV camera, unless you are satisfied with 2 minute flights.

The flight characteristics with this frame are quite different than the original E010. It is quite nimble and tends to coast, or drift, most likely due to the low drag profile. To explain what I mean by "coast", imagine flying the drone in forward, then suddenly setting the pitch control to neutral. The drone pitch angle will level out, but continue to fly forward for some distance while it slows down. A reverse control input is required to stop the drone when desired. It's not really a bad thing, but I just wanted to let you know about because it is a bit different than the stock drone characteristics.

Printing:
Frame - simply print it flat on the bed, with the flat side of the down. No supports required.
Battery Holder - Will not need supports if printed vertically, with the forward face flat on the bed (the forward face is the end with the lip, as shown in the attached picture).

description.text: This is some art converted from 2D from a Disney Star Wars art therapy book.
This is some art converted from 2D from a Disney Star Wars art therapy book.

I wanted something unique to go with the shelf brackets I made.
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2743913

Since my printer is not 24" long, I had to come up with something that I can print a little at a time and put them together. Something modular...

I came up with this. These are really simple square tiles that have dovetail joints built into them so you can slide a dovetail into them to hold them in place.

You will need excellent printer adhesion to make these since they are quite large and have a huge surface area where they are touching the build plate.

As for the dovetail inserts, they are designed tight. Once they go in, you may need pliers to remove them. Also, keep in mind that different brand materials will shrink a little differently between brands and types. What prints well for me, may be slightly off for you, so you may need to tweak the scale of the dovetails slightly to get them to fit snug.

I made a few different versions of the tile to give maximum flexibility on how to use them.

Note - These are made from 3D printed plastic. They are not meant to be used for heavy things like books. These are just meant to hold small objects such as displaying the cool 3D things you've printed out.

Also note, I'm still working on adding to this. I'll be making a rail for the front which should help make it even more sturdy and might even design a truss bottom for the dovetails... but I can only draw so fast in my spare time.. lol

This is an under-string banjo mute for a 5/8" bridge set up. I've not yet tested this print and would appreciate feedback if you try it.

It needs to be printed in a flexible material (maybe a semiflex) and should be placed under the strings on the head of the instrument. If the mute pushes the strings out of the notches on the bridge, it is either a height problem or infill problem; you can fix either of these in your slicer.

The design is such that it should mute the strings by applying a slight pressure while preventing the head from moving freely. This results in a plunkier sound which I've found (from my mickey-moused prototype) to be desirable for certain songs (a frailed version of Moon River (I haven't tabbed it out yet, but it'll be on banjohangout once I'm done), for example, sounds rather nice with the mute)

remixed_from.title: MM3 Fan Duct for dual extruder

title: MM3 Fan Duct for dual extruder

description.text:
I found maddavo's fan duct to not function with the way I had my hot ends mounted. I made the following changes to adjust this part for my use:

  1. Widened the gap for the hot ends, to allow for hot ends with silicone covers.
  2. Made the portion of the blower between the hot end and carriage much thinner, so as to fit comfortably.
  3. Adjusted the mounting holes so that the fan could be mounted either closer, or further from the build platform.
  4. Reduced the lip of the fan mount, so that the fans I had on hand don't get caught on it.
  5. Added screw mounts for the fans to make them more secure.
  6. Angled the vents that surround the hot end downwards, in the hope that it improves airflow.

title: Motorcycle GPS holder - updated with new version

description.text:
Update: I have it on the bike for about half a year now.
Tested it on a longer road and it still OK. We'll see how will it last after the winter (I left it on the bike in the garage - no heating) This is my first project after I bought my printer.
It was made in Openscad and it is to hold my GPS bag:
http://www.louis.de/_10d2790dfbb4c522fb9c76b088ad51edb3/index.php?topic=artnr_gr&artnr_gr=10032971 I redesigned some parts because I realized they were to sharp!!!
I leave everything here... you decide which version you like the more :)
If you have improvement ideas or realised some part is wrong let me know. Version 2 updates:
  • Longer mounting ring so it gives more space for me to put in the keys and turn the ignition: It is 75 mm in total because that is the space between my handle bar spacers.
  • under rings are smaller for saving print time and material
  • rounded edges on more pieces including the mounting plates
    • Version 3.0:
  • 08 Mounting head.... now has 4 holes so the plate can be mounted in anydirection this way the bag can be fitted in landscape or portrait mode and the little support under the last hole reduced because you couldn't mount the screw in it :(
    • Old description:
    In the End I used the 4mm ones from the GPS bag and mounted the bag to the frame with other ones.
    The quick release is my design so I don't know how well will hold on a bumpy road :)
    The plate is designed separately so it is easier to print and this way anyone can use it with another quick release system.
    You also gonna need 2 x 5 /20 mm screws + nuts for the adjustments.
    The width of the 3 plated holder is 3 mm, the middle piece is 2.5 thick so after print it will fit without problems... at least in my printer :)

They are all printed from ABS.
settings I used on my printer: 235 degrees nozzle, at 0,2 mm thickens, speed 60 mm/s, 2 layers, infill 15-20% to add more strength to the parts + the mounting rings need to be drilled.
The nuts were glued in after print as well as the screws in to the covers, so they stay were they supposed to.

title: Toy in a Box -  in memory of my Grandpa
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a patent my Granpa applied for in 1967. It was approved in January 1968. It just was a test how to apply for an patent, he wasn`t intressted in earnig money with it. Once he said to my Dad " I am a Maker, not a tradesman" :D

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NUSezMFO4bA

I made my first own 3D-Print-Project, now, nearly excatly 50 Years after the approval of his patent in january 1968. I changed the ladder parts to keap the ladder modular, but made them better printable and stable. I think that i act in my Grandpas intrests with this adjustments.

I hope you like it. The patent expire some years ago i just wrote the number in tribute to my grandpa on the case.

thnx for reading, enjoy your day !

title: Monoprice Select Mini Heated Bed Fix Kit Complete (Chain Update)

description.text:
SMOOTH FIT CABLE DRAG CHAIN. SAFELY REROUTE BADLY PLACED HEATED BED WIRES USING THE CHAIN Pro ENERGY CHAIN FOR MONOPRICE SELECT MINI.

-Restricted radial motion version-
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2758569/zip

+PRINTS A MOVABLE 4 PACK. Print and give them a little click to start the chain reaction.
+DRAMATICALLY IMPROVED STOPS to properly limit movement.
+All HARDWARE INCLUDED accepting screws glues and kazoos

INCLUDES
+Fitted Bed Mount, Use existing holes as pilot holes for bed mount.
+Clip together construction prints Easily on monoprice bed.
+Fitted last and first Links.
+Backwards Compatible (MK-II & MP CABLE CHAIN).
+What dreams are made of.

INSTALLATION GENERAL
+Three holes need to be drilled into the back of the cabinet below the bed.
+Open bottom of printer using proper sized philips (star) Screwdriver.
+Reposition wires to prevent wire damage during drilling.
+Use step drill to prevent sudden drill penetration.
+Fit these holes AFTER BED MOUNT and CHAIN configuration.
+If you are doing this repair on a new printer and are just adding wire you can appropriate
heat shrink tubing without the use of solder and still have satisfactory results.
+Glue type tube of 3:1 ratio preferred.
Wires sized appropriately similar will not get very hot in use.

CHOICE OF REPAIR SOLUTION
Install a new heated bed power source and relay or solder equivalent longer wires to the bed or use the existing wires. This is a reasonable route for the wires.
Existing wires connector clips should fit through the chain although if you chose to solder in a few more inches of wire it allows for easy cable threading.

BED MOUNT
+Remove the bed to install the Bed mount.
+Drill the four small holes on back of bed with a clearance hole for your smallest nut and
bolts set of four that's at least 3/8" in length.

PRINTING 'ROOF' OF 4xMK_III
+A Bic hex type ball-point pen can be dropped into the 4xMK_III print as the crest of the
side walls begins to show.
The pen is a good size to support the first layer of the top of the chain.

DO NOT use Skirt or Brim or support as these will mess up the chain. All layer height
setting have worked well on this print.

PREFERRED SETTING INFO
+Prints best as positioned in STL File.
+Glass Bed used in testing models.
Multiple links not recommended without a piece of glass.
+3.5mm or greater retract.
+30mm/sec print speed +/- Depending on quality and ambient conditions.
+Clear Tough PLA or PET-G. Top Range of heat for good layer adhesion.
+NO BRIM / NO SKIRT / NO SUPPORT
+.175 layer height works very well.
+4 mm wall
+100% Fill
+Bic pen (Hex shaped) inserted just before first layer of top of chain to ensure support
without getting in the way of the nozzle.

This is a heated bed mount for the Raspberry Pi v2.1 camera for the Prusa i3 MK2(S). It slides onto the aluminum arm of the Y-carriage. The camera can be tilted, swiveled, and raised/lowered. There's also a slot on the end of the arm to guide the ribbon cable.

Non-printed parts:
1xM3x12 and nut
1xM3x20 and nut
2xM2x16 and nuts

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I used PETG, PLA would probably warp being that close to the heated bed.
The arm and case cover need to be rotated in your slicer. The arm should have the part that slides onto the Y-carriage facing up, and the cover needs to be flipped so the inside is facing up.

Post-Processing

There are two 0.45mm walls built into the case back design for support that need to be cut out.
If you want that I make some other type of keychain feel free to comment. Any question is welcome :)

CR-10

Hi Guys
This is the infamous Prometheus Lens that Bungie got all wrong when they released it. I just had to model it.
It has a lot of parts but the prints are reasonably straightforward. I build one entire side on a flat surface to keep the gun straight then glue the individual parts from the other side onto that. This is the only way you won't end up with a banana. It has a hollowed out middle section so you can add lights like mine if you wish. I used a small supermarket torch that shines through a hole onto the crystal and some blue LED strips inside to light up the clear sections. The six rings at the back and the middle top section of this part need to be printed in clear material.
I glued the crystal directly to the pointers though the real one just kind of floats in space.
It's a big project so be prepared for a lot of work but it came out ok I think.
As always, have fun, happy printing and check out my facebook page Bigbangcollectables
17/1/18 UPDATE. Front body parts added. Soz.

print_settings.Notes:: the basin will come in upside down so if you rotate it right side up no support is needed.

description.text:
Watching a YouTube video from Doctor Faust I was inspired to design and build these wash basins for cleaning my paint brushes. The basin on the right and the top are the first design and the basin on the left is the improved. After trying the first design I discovered 2 things, 1 I needed to raise the joint to allow a higher water level and 2 it leaked. It was easy to adjust the joint to be higher. I found coating the inside with polyurethane solved the problem of leaking. Since PLA plastic is water soluble I will probably coat the outside of the basins and tops with polyurethane as well.

assembled they are just under 4" outside diameter and approximately 5" tall with a 1 1/4" diameter opening.

the basin will come in upside down so if you rotate it right side up no support is needed.
if you print with PLA as I did you will need to coat them with something to make them water proof like polyurethane. if you use ABS you can use Acetone to seal them against leaking

description.text:
Podéis escalar en Z la pieza para hacerla con el largo que gustéis. Yo la he impreso en vertical pero creo que en horizontal también se puede hacer sin puentes (la próxima la haré en horizontal). Creía que con las medidas que puse iba a quedarse con holgura pero al imprimirla me salieron más grandes y tuve que limarlas poco a poco para que se pudieran montar sin tener que desarmar la impresora. Os dejo el fichero en formato Freecad para quien guste mejorarla.

Traducción Google:

You can scale the piece in Z to make it as long as you like. I have printed it vertically but I think that horizontally it can also be done without bridges (the next one will be horizontal). I thought that with the measures that I put it was going to stay with slack but when printing it they left me bigger and I had to file them little by little so that they could be assembled without having to disassemble the printer. I leave the file in Freecad format for those who like to improve it.
